holdings.core_holding: GDPR consent is required for including subscriber personal data in telephone directories published by third-party providers, and such consent may be given to the operator or any directory provider.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 4(11) of the GDPR, which constitutes the provision applicable to the facts at issue in the main proceedings, defines the 'consent of the data subject' as requiring a 'freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous' indication of the data subject's wishes in the form of a statement or of 'a clear affirmative action' signifying agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It follows from a contextual and systematic interpretation of Article 12 of Directive 2002/58 that the consent under Article 12(2) relates to the purpose of the publication of personal data in a public directory and not to the identity of any particular directory provider.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Article 1(1) of Directive 2002/58 provides, inter alia, for the harmonisation of the national provisions required to ensure an equivalent level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms, and in particular the right to privacy and confidentiality, with regard to the processing of personal data in the electronic communications sector.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows that such consent is necessary in order for the personal data relating to the subscriber of a telephone service operator to be included in directories.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, such prior information gives the subscriber concerned the opportunity to give consent to the publication of his or her personal data in public directories, such consent being necessary for the purposes of such a publication.

holdings.direction_justification: Confirms that GDPR-standard consent is required for directory inclusion, strengthening subscriber control over personal data publication.

holdings.core_holding: A subscriber's request to withdraw personal data from telephone directories constitutes exercise of the right to erasure under Article 17 GDPR.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under the second sentence of Article 12(2) of Directive 2002/58, subscribers must have, inter alia, the opportunity to have the personal data relating to them withdrawn from public directories.
interpretation.systematic_quote: However, the grant of such an opportunity to subscribers does not constitute, as regards the providers of directories, a specific obligation, within the meaning of Article 95 of the GDPR, which would make it possible to exclude the application of the relevant provisions of that regulation.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Directive 2002/58 does not contain any indications as to the modalities, implementation and consequences of requests to obtain the withdrawal of personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from Article 17(1)(b) and (d) of the GDPR that the data subject is to have the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her and that the controller is to have the obligation to erase those data without undue delay.

holdings.direction_justification: Classifies withdrawal requests as erasure rights under Article 17 GDPR, giving subscribers stronger legal protection than mere rectification.

holdings.core_holding: A DPA may require directory providers to take measures to inform third-party controllers (operators and other directory providers) of a subscriber's consent withdrawal.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 24 of the GDPR, that provision requires that, taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing, the controller implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with that regulation.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It follows from the general obligations laid down in Article 5(2) and Article 24 of the GDPR, read in conjunction with Article 19 thereof, that a controller of personal data, such as Proximus, must, by means of appropriate technical and organisational measures, inform the other providers of directories that have received such data from it of the withdrawal of the data subject's consent addressed to it.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In order to ensure the effectiveness of the right of the data subject to withdraw his or her consent provided for in Article 7(3) of the GDPR and to ensure that the data subject's consent is strictly linked to the purpose for which it was given, the controller to which the data subject has notified the withdrawal of his or her consent to the processing of his or her personal data is in fact required to communicate that withdrawal to any person who has forwarded those data to it and to the person to whom it has, in turn, forwarded those data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 5(2) and Article 24 of the GDPR impose general accountability and compliance requirements upon controllers of personal data.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Such an approach would thus be contrary to Article 7(3) of the GDPR, which provides that it must be as easy to withdraw, as to give, consent to the processing of personal data.

holdings.direction_justification: Imposes chain notification obligations on controllers to facilitate consent withdrawal, making it easier for subscribers to exercise their rights.

holdings.core_holding: A DPA may order directory providers to take reasonable steps to inform search engines of erasure requests from subscribers.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 17(2) of the GDPR imposes the obligation on the controller which has made the personal data public, taking account of available technology and the cost of implementation, to take reasonable steps, including technical measures, to inform controllers which are processing the personal data that the data subject has requested the erasure by such controllers of any links to, or copy or replication of, those personal data.
interpretation.teleological_quote: As is apparent from recital 66 of the GDPR, the objective of that obligation is to strengthen the right to be forgotten in the online environment, and therefore specifically applies to information made available on the internet by search engine providers that process data published online.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: In circumstances such as those at issue in the main proceedings, it must be concluded that a controller such as Proximus is required, under Article 17(2) of the GDPR, to ensure that reasonable steps are taken to inform search engine providers of the request addressed to it by the subscriber of a telephone service operator for erasure of his or her personal data.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In accordance with settled case-law, the activity of a search engine consisting in finding information published or placed on the internet by third parties, indexing it automatically, storing it temporarily and, finally, making it available to internet users according to a particular order of preference must be classified as 'processing' of personal data within the meaning of Article 4(2) of the GDPR when that information contains personal data.

holdings.direction_justification: Extends directory providers' obligations to include notifying search engines, strengthening the right to be forgotten in the online environment.

holdings.core_holding: The remedies under Articles 77-79 GDPR may be exercised concurrently and independently, with Member States setting procedural rules ensuring effective protection and consistent application.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Thus, those provisions of Regulation 2016/679 offer different remedies to persons claiming that that regulation has been infringed, it being understood that each of those remedies must be capable of being exercised 'without prejudice' to the others.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Although the EU legislature has expressly regulated the relationship between the remedies provided for by Regulation 2016/679 in the event of the supervisory authorities or courts of several Member States being seised simultaneously in respect of an instance of processing of personal data carried out by the same controller, it must be observed that this is not the case as regards the remedies provided for in Articles 77 to 79 of that regulation.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Lastly, regarding the objectives pursued by that regulation, it is apparent, in particular, from recital 10 thereof that the aim of that regulation is to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data within the European Union.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows, first of all, from the wording of those provisions that Regulation 2016/679 does not provide for any priority or exclusive competence or jurisdiction or for any rule of precedence in respect of the assessment carried out by the authority or by the courts referred to therein as to whether there is an infringement of the rights conferred by that regulation.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In addition, Article 19(1) TEU requires Member States to provide remedies sufficient to ensure effective judicial protection in the fields covered by EU law.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Making several remedies available also strengthens the objective set out in recital 141 of Regulation 2016/679 of guaranteeing for every data subject who considers that his or her rights under that regulation are infringed the right to an effective judicial remedy in accordance with Article 47 of the Charter.

holdings.direction_justification: Permits data subjects to pursue multiple remedies concurrently, maximizing avenues for enforcement of their rights.

holdings.core_holding: The right of access under Article 15(1)(c) GDPR entails an obligation to provide data subjects with the actual identity of recipients to whom their data have been disclosed, unless identification is impossible or the request is manifestly unfounded or excessive.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It should be noted that the terms 'recipients' and 'categories of recipient' in that provision are used in succession, without it being possible to infer an order of priority between them.
interpretation.systematic_quote: In the fourth place, the Court has previously held that the exercise of that right of access must enable the data subject to verify not only that the data concerning him or her are correct, but also that they are processed in a lawful manner, and in particular that they have been disclosed to authorised recipients.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Lastly, as regards the purpose of the GDPR, it should be pointed out that its purpose is, inter alia, as is apparent from recital 10 of that regulation, to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons within the European Union.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from Article 15(1)(c) of the GDPR that the data subject has the right to obtain from the controller confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning him or her are being processed and, where that is the case, access to the personal data and information about the recipients or categories of recipient to whom the personal data have been or will be disclosed.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In particular, that right of access is necessary to enable the data subject to exercise, depending on the circumstances, his or her right to rectification, right to erasure ('right to be forgotten') or right to restriction of processing, conferred, respectively, by Articles 16, 17 and 18 of the GDPR.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: That right must be considered in relation to its function in society and be balanced against other fundamental rights, in accordance with the principle of proportionality.

holdings.direction_justification: The Court interprets the right of access broadly to require disclosure of specific recipient identities, not just categories, thereby enhancing data subject control over their personal data.

balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection right of access prevails, though the Court acknowledges it is not absolute and must be balanced with other fundamental rights per the principle of proportionality.

holdings.core_holding: The exception to the controller's obligation to provide information applies to all personal data not collected directly from the data subject, including data generated by the controller itself.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It must be noted that the wording of Article 14(5)(c) of the GDPR does not limit the exception which it lays down merely to personal data obtained by the controller from a person other than the data subject, nor does it exclude data generated by the controller itself, in the performance of its tasks, from such data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Therefore, it follows from the combined interpretation of Articles 13 and 14 of the GDPR that both personal data obtained by the controller from a person other than the data subject, and data generated by the controller itself – which, on account of their nature, have also not been obtained from the data subject – fall within the scope of Article 14.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Article 14(5)(c) of the GDPR must be interpreted in a way which is consistent with the objective pursued by that regulation, which consists, inter alia, as is apparent from Article 1 thereof, read in the light of recitals 1 and 10 thereof, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 14(1), (2) and (4) of that regulation specifies the information which the controller must provide to the data subject, within the meaning of Article 4(1) of that regulation, where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In order to determine whether that exception covers personal data generated by the controller itself – in the performance of its tasks – from data obtained from a person other than the data subject, it is necessary, in accordance with settled case-law, to consider not only the wording of the provision laying down that exception but also its context and the objectives pursued by the legislation of which it forms part.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of the exception to information obligations reduces controller burdens by exempting them from providing information for controller-generated data when statutory conditions are met.

holdings.core_holding: Supervisory authorities are competent to verify whether Member State law provides appropriate protective measures under Article 14(5)(c), but this does not extend to verifying Article 32 security measures.

interpretation.semantic_quote: The GDPR does not include any provision such as to exclude certain aspects of the application of the exception laid down in Article 14(5)(c) of that regulation from the competence of those supervisory authorities.
interpretation.systematic_quote: In the light of the respective wording of those two provisions, it should be noted that the obligations enshrined in Article 32 of the GDPR, which must be complied with in all circumstances and irrespective of whether or not there is an obligation to provide information under Article 14 of that regulation, differ in nature and scope from the obligation to provide information laid down in Article 14 of that regulation.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The provisions of EU or Member State law which provide for such measures and to which the controller is subject must guarantee a level of protection of the data subject with regard to the processing of his or her personal data which is at least equivalent to that provided for in Article 14(1) to (4) of that regulation.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: As regards the competence of the supervisory authorities, Article 55(1) of that regulation provides that each supervisory authority is competent, on the territory of its own Member State, for the performance of the tasks assigned to it and the exercise of the powers conferred on it in accordance with that regulation.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Article 32 obliges the controller and any processor of that controller to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure an adequate level of security for the processing of personal data.

holdings.direction_justification: DPA competence is affirmed for verifying protective measures (pro-data subject) but limited by excluding Article 32 security measures from the scope of review (pro-controller).

holdings.core_holding: Processing is necessary for contract performance under Article 6(1)(b) only if objectively indispensable for the main contractual purpose, which is not met when the contract expressly prohibits disclosure.

interpretation.semantic_quote: In order for the processing of personal data to be regarded as necessary for the performance of a contract within the meaning of that provision, it must be objectively indispensable for a purpose that is integral to the contractual obligation intended for the data subject.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The essential feature of acquiring an indirect shareholding, through a trust company, in an investment fund offering shares for public subscription is precisely the anonymity of the partners, including in relations between the partners themselves.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The objective pursued by the GDPR, as is apparent from Article 1 thereof and recitals 1 and 10 thereof, consists, inter alia, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: That provision provides that processing of personal data is lawful if it is 'necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party or in order to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract'.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has held previously, in order for the processing of personal data to be regarded as necessary for the performance of a contract within the meaning of that provision, it must be objectively indispensable for a purpose that is integral to the contractual obligation intended for the data subject.

holdings.direction_justification: Sets high threshold for contract necessity requiring objective indispensability, protecting data subjects from disclosure contrary to contractual expectations.

balancing.necessity_summary: Processing must be objectively indispensable and essential with no workable less intrusive alternatives for the main contract subject matter to be achieved.

holdings.core_holding: Legitimate interests processing under Article 6(1)(f) requires strict necessity and a balancing test where data subject interests may override, particularly when disclosure was not reasonably expected.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That provision provides that the processing of personal data is lawful if it is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The condition relating to the need for processing must be examined in conjunction with the 'data minimisation' principle enshrined in Article 5(1)(c) of the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Recital 47 of the GDPR states that the interests and fundamental rights of the data subject may in particular override the interest of the data controller where personal data are processed in circumstances where data subjects do not reasonably expect such processing.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: That provision lays down three cumulative conditions so that the processing of personal data covered by that provision is lawful.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has held previously, that provision lays down three cumulative conditions so that the processing of personal data covered by that provision is lawful, namely, first, the pursuit of a legitimate interest by the data controller or by a third party; second, the need to process personal data for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued; and, third, that the interests or fundamental freedoms and rights of the person concerned by the data protection do not take precedence.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: It is necessary to attach particular significance to the fact that it is likely, with regard, in particular, to the contractual provisions referred to in paragraph 45 of this judgment, that the indirect partners of such an investment fund could not reasonably expect, at the time when their personal data are collected, that those personal data are disclosed to third parties.

holdings.direction_justification: Court emphasizes strict necessity, less intrusive alternatives, data minimisation, and reasonable expectations favoring data subject protection over third party interests.

balancing.necessity_summary: Processing must be strictly necessary with the legitimate interest not reasonably achievable by less restrictive means equally appropriate for achieving the purpose.
balancing.balance_summary: Data subjects' interest in confidentiality may override other partners' interest in obtaining contact details, especially where contractual provisions ensure confidentiality.

holdings.core_holding: Legal obligation under Article 6(1)(c) can derive from Member State case-law provided it is clear, precise, foreseeable, meets a public interest objective, and is proportionate.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That provision provides that the processing of personal data is lawful if processing is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR specifies, inter alia, in that respect, that the processing must be based on EU law or on Member State law to which the controller is subject.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That legal basis must meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR specifies, inter alia, in that respect, that the processing must be based on EU law or on Member State law to which the controller is subject, and that that legal basis must meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As is apparent from recital 41 of that regulation, such case-law must be clear and precise and its application must be foreseeable by those persons subject to it, in accordance with the case-law of the Court.

holdings.direction_justification: Court sets out conditions for legal obligation basis without definitively ruling whether German case-law meets them, leaving determination to national court.

balancing.necessity_summary: Processing based on legal obligation must be strictly necessary, with the referring court to ascertain whether less restrictive measures exist.

holdings.core_holding: The collection by tax authorities of a Member State from an economic operator of personal data is subject to GDPR requirements, including Article 5(1) principles.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under Article 4(2) of that regulation, the collection, consultation, disclosure by transmission and making available in any way of personal data constitute 'processing' within the meaning of that regulation.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is apparent from recital 19 of Regulation 2016/679, the reason for that exception is that the processing of personal data for such purposes by the competent authorities is governed by a specific EU legal act, namely Directive 2016/680, which was adopted on the same day as Regulation 2016/679.
interpretation.teleological_quote: As is apparent from recital 10 thereof, Regulation 2016/679 aims, inter alia, to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons within the European Union.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 4(1) of Regulation 2016/679 specifies that 'personal data' is to mean any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has held, that provision lays down exceptions to the scope of that regulation, as defined in Article 2(1) thereof, which must be interpreted strictly.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope confirms tax authorities are subject to data protection requirements when collecting personal data.

holdings.core_holding: Tax authorities cannot derogate from Article 5(1) GDPR unless granted that right by a legislative measure meeting Article 23(1) requirements.

interpretation.semantic_quote: However, Article 23 of Regulation 2016/679 authorises the European Union and Member States to adopt a 'legislative measure' restricting the scope of the obligations and rights provided for, inter alia, in Article 5 of that regulation.
interpretation.systematic_quote: In that regard, it is apparent from recital 41 of Regulation 2016/679 that the reference, in that regulation, to a 'legislative measure' does not necessarily require a legislative act adopted by a parliament.
interpretation.teleological_quote: As a preliminary point, it should be recalled that, as is apparent from recital 10 thereof, Regulation 2016/679 aims, inter alia, to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons within the European Union.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from the foregoing considerations that the tax authorities of a Member State cannot derogate from the provisions of Article 5 of Regulation 2016/679 in the absence of a clear and precise legal basis under EU or national law.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In accordance with the first sentence of Article 52(1) of the Charter, any limitation on the exercise of the rights and freedoms recognised by the Charter must be provided for by law.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Any measure adopted under Article 23 of Regulation 2016/679 must be clear and precise and its application be foreseeable to persons subject to it.

holdings.direction_justification: Requires explicit legislative basis before tax authorities can limit Article 5(1) rights, preventing unilateral derogation by authorities.

other_rights: right to respect for private life
right to protection of personal data
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Charter rights to privacy and data protection require that any limitation be provided for by clear and precise law with foreseeable application.

holdings.core_holding: Tax authorities may require disclosure of taxpayer data from internet service providers provided the data are necessary for specific purposes and collection period does not exceed strict necessity.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 5(1)(b) of Regulation 2016/679 provides that personal data are to be collected, inter alia, for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes.
interpretation.systematic_quote: In accordance with Article 5(1)(c) of Regulation 2016/679, personal data are to be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.
interpretation.teleological_quote: It should be recalled that the collection of tax and combating tax fraud must be regarded as tasks carried out in the public interest within the meaning of point (e) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of Regulation 2016/679.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows that the controller, including where it acts in connection with a task which it has been charged with carrying out in the public interest, may not proceed, in a general and undifferentiated manner, with the collection of personal data.
reasoning.case_law_quote: According to settled case-law, derogations and limitations in relation to the principle of protection of such data must apply only in so far as is strictly necessary.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: In order to satisfy the requirement of proportionality to which Article 5(1)(c) of Regulation 2016/679 gives expression, the legislation which provides the basis for the processing must lay down clear and precise rules governing the scope and application of the measure in question.

holdings.direction_justification: Permits tax authority data collection but imposes strict necessity and purpose limitation requirements protecting data subjects.

balancing.necessity_summary: Data collection by tax authorities must be limited to what is strictly necessary for the specific purposes, with the period not exceeding what is strictly necessary for the public interest objective.

holdings.core_holding: Processing personal data for prosecution serves a different purpose than collection for detection and investigation, but such subsequent processing is permitted under Directive 2016/680 Article 4(2) conditions.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It is apparent from the various language versions of that provision, in particular those in Bulgarian, Spanish, German, Greek, English and Italian, that the different purposes referred to in Article 1(1) of that directive correspond to the 'prevention', 'detection', 'investigation' and 'prosecution' of criminal offences and 'the execution of criminal penalties', including the 'safeguarding' against 'threats to public security' and the 'prevention' of such threats.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 4(2) of that directive, in the light of recital 29 thereof, authorises subsequent processing of personal data for a purpose other than that for which those data were collected, where that purpose is among those set out in Article 1(1) of that directive and that processing satisfies the two conditions laid down in Article 4(2)(a) and (b).
interpretation.teleological_quote: It follows from this that the EU legislature sought to adopt rules corresponding to the specific features which characterise the activities carried out by the competent authorities in the field governed by that directive, while taking account of the fact that they constitute distinct activities serving purposes specific to them.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It can thus be inferred from the very wording of Article 1(1) of Directive 2016/680, read in conjunction with Article 4(2) thereof, that, where personal data have been collected for the purposes of the 'detection' and 'investigation' of a criminal offence and have subsequently been processed for the purposes of 'prosecution', that collection and that processing serve different purposes.
reasoning.case_law_quote: According to settled case-law, it is necessary, for the interpretation of a provision of EU law, that account be taken not only of its wording, but also of its context and the objectives pursued by the rules of which it is part.

holdings.direction_justification: The Court clarifies that different purposes exist but permits subsequent processing under specified conditions, neither expanding nor restricting data subject rights.

balancing.necessity_summary: Processing for prosecution must be necessary and proportionate to that purpose under Article 4(2)(b) of Directive 2016/680.

holdings.core_holding: The GDPR applies to processing of personal data by a public prosecutor's office when defending the State in civil damages proceedings using data originally collected for criminal purposes.

interpretation.semantic_quote: First of all, it must be borne in mind that 'personal data', within the meaning of Article 4(1) of the GDPR, means 'any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person', it being understood that, according to the case-law, that definition is applicable where, by reason of its content, purpose and effect, the information in question is linked to a particular person.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is therefore appropriate for those fields to be addressed by a directive that lays down the specific rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Those definitions reflect the aim of the EU legislature to assign a broad scope to those two concepts.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It should be noted that Article 2(1) of the GDPR defines broadly the material scope of that regulation, which includes any 'processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means and … the processing other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system'.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In that regard, the Court has held that, as follows from recital 19 of that regulation, the reason for that exception is that the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purposes set out in Article 2(2)(d) of the GDPR is governed by a specific EU legal act, namely Directive 2016/680, which was adopted on the same day as the GDPR.

holdings.direction_justification: The Court interprets GDPR scope broadly to include processing by public authorities for civil defense purposes, ensuring data protection applies.

holdings.core_holding: Processing personal data by a public prosecutor's office for State defense in damages proceedings may be lawful under Article 6(1)(e) GDPR as a task carried out in the public interest.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It should be noted that, as the Commission correctly stated in its written observations, it is clear from the wording of the second subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR that the processing of personal data by a public authority in the performance of its tasks cannot come within the scope of point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, relating to the processing of personal data that is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller.
interpretation.systematic_quote: As follows from recital 47 of the GDPR and as the Commission has claimed, that latter provision cannot apply to such data processing, since the legal basis of that processing must be provided for by the legislature.
interpretation.teleological_quote: First, by exercising the procedural rights that it enjoys as defendant, that public authority preserves the legal certainty of the acts carried out and decisions adopted in the public interest that are being called into question by the applicant.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It must be borne in mind that Article 6 of the GDPR lists, in a restrictive manner, the cases in which processing of personal data can be regarded as lawful.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In that regard, it is irrelevant that, in an action for damages against the State, the public prosecutor's office is, in its capacity as defendant, on an equal footing with the other parties, and does not exercise public powers, as is the case in the performance of its tasks in criminal matters.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Second, by its claims and arguments in defence, that public authority is capable of pointing, where such is the case, to the potentially unfounded or excessive nature of the applicant's claims for compensation, with a view, in particular, to preventing the performance of the tasks carried out in the public interest that are being called into question in the action for damages from being hindered by the prospect of actions for damages, where those tasks are liable to harm the interests of individuals.

holdings.direction_justification: The Court permits public authorities to process personal data for litigation defense under the public interest basis, facilitating their defensive capabilities.

balancing.necessity_summary: Processing must be necessary for the public prosecutor's office's performance of its task carried out in the public interest.

holdings.core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82(1) GDPR fulfils an exclusively compensatory function, not a punitive or deterrent one.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Accordingly, Article 82(1) of the GDPR has been interpreted as meaning that the right to compensation laid down in that provision, in particular in the case of non-material damage, fulfils an exclusively compensatory function, in that financial compensation based on that provision must allow the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in full, and not a deterrent or punitive function.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The right of any person to seek compensation for damage reinforces the operational nature of the protection rules laid down by that regulation and is likely to discourage the reoccurrence of unlawful conduct.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 82 of the GDPR fulfils a function that is compensatory and not punitive, contrary to other provisions of that regulation also contained in Chapter VIII thereof, namely Articles 83 and 84, which have, for their part, essentially a punitive purpose.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, Article 82 of the GDPR fulfils a function that is compensatory and not punitive.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding clarifies the nature of compensation without expanding or restricting rights; it confirms compensation must be full but not punitive.

holdings.core_holding: The severity and intentional nature of a GDPR infringement need not be taken into account when determining compensation under Article 82(1).

interpretation.semantic_quote: The exclusively compensatory function of the right to compensation provided for in Article 82(1) of the GDPR precludes taking into account the potentially intentional nature of the infringement of that regulation.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That amount must, however, be fixed in such a way as to compensate in full for the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 82 does not require that the severity of that fault is taken into consideration when setting the amount of the compensation allocated for non-material damage under that provision.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It must, however, be pointed out, first, that the controller's liability under Article 82 of the GDPR is subject to fault on the part of the controller, which is presupposed unless it proves that it is not in any way responsible for the event giving rise to the damage.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding benefits controllers by not increasing compensation for intentional violations, but also confirms presumed fault liability.

holdings.core_holding: Non-material damage from a data breach is not by its nature less significant than physical injury when determining compensation.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It should also be noted that recitals 75 and 85 of the GDPR set out various circumstances that could be classified as 'physical, material or non-material damage' without establishing a hierarchy between them.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Recitals 75 and 85 of the GDPR set out various circumstances that could be classified as 'physical, material or non-material damage' without establishing a hierarchy between them nor do they indicate that harm resulting from a data breach is, by its very nature, less significant than physical injury.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Assuming, as a matter of principle, that physical injury is, by its nature, more serious than non-material damage, would risk calling into question the principle of full and effective compensation for the damage suffered.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: In the absence of EU rules on the matter, it is for the national legal order of each Member State to establish procedural rules for actions intended to safeguard the rights of individuals, in accordance with the principle of procedural autonomy.
reasoning.case_law_quote: According to settled case-law, in the absence of EU rules on the matter, it is for the national legal order of each Member State to establish procedural rules for actions intended to safeguard the rights of individuals.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Data subjects should receive full and effective compensation for the damage they have suffered.

holdings.direction_justification: Elevating non-material damage to equal status with physical injury strengthens data subject compensation rights.

holdings.core_holding: Courts may award minimal compensation for non-serious damage provided it fully compensates the damage actually suffered.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 82(1) of the GDPR does not require that, following a proven infringement of provisions of that regulation, the damage alleged by the data subject must reach a 'de minimis threshold' in order to give rise to a right to compensation.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Such considerations do not preclude the national courts from awarding compensation of a small amount provided that such compensation fully offsets that damage.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Where a person succeeds in demonstrating that the infringement of the GDPR has caused him or her damage within the meaning of Article 82 of that regulation, it follows that the criteria for assessing the compensation due must be prescribed within the legal system of each Member State.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has held that Article 82(1) of the GDPR does not require that, following a proven infringement of provisions of that regulation, the damage alleged by the data subject must reach a 'de minimis threshold' in order to give rise to a right to compensation.

holdings.direction_justification: Confirms no de minimis threshold (pro-data subject) but permits minimal/symbolic awards for minor damage (pro-controller).

holdings.core_holding: Identity theft requires actual misuse of identity by a third party, but compensation for data theft is not limited to cases of proven identity theft.

interpretation.semantic_quote: The concepts of identity 'theft' and 'fraud' are interchangeable and no distinction can be drawn between them.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Among the various concepts set out in the lists in recitals 75 and 85 of the GDPR, 'loss of control' or the inability 'to exercise control' over personal data are distinguished from identity 'theft' or 'fraud'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: However, it must be stated, in that regard, that compensation for non-material damage caused by the theft of personal data, pursuant to Article 82(1) of the GDPR, cannot be limited to cases where it is shown that that data theft subsequently gave rise to identity theft or fraud.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: The theft of a data subject's personal data gives rise to a right to compensation for non-material damage suffered, under Article 82(1) of the GDPR, if the three conditions laid down in that provision apply.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The theft of a data subject's personal data gives rise to a right to compensation for non-material damage suffered, under Article 82(1) of the GDPR, if the three conditions laid down in that provision apply.

holdings.direction_justification: Clarifies that compensation is available for data theft even without proven identity theft or fraud, lowering the burden for claimants.

holdings.core_holding: Online publication of declarations of private interests is precluded where it includes name-specific data about declarant's spouse, close relatives, or transactions exceeding EUR 3000.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under Article 7(e) of Directive 95/46 and point (e) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, which are mentioned by the referring court in its first question, processing that is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller is lawful.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR specifies, in respect of those two situations where processing is lawful, that the processing must be based on EU law or on Member State law to which the controller is subject, and that that legal basis must meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In accordance with Article 1(1) of Directive 95/46, read in conjunction with recital 10 thereof, and Article 1(2) of the GDPR, read in conjunction with recitals 4 and 10 thereof, that directive and that regulation have the objective in particular of ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons with respect to the processing of personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 7 of Directive 95/46 and the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR set out an exhaustive and restrictive list of the cases in which processing of personal data can be regarded as lawful.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, the fundamental rights to respect for private life and to the protection of personal data, guaranteed in Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter, are not absolute rights, but must be considered in relation to their function in society and be weighed against other fundamental rights.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: It must be borne in mind that an objective of general interest may not be pursued without having regard to the fact that it must be reconciled with the fundamental rights affected by the measure, by properly balancing the objective of general interest against the rights at issue.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text allowed Member States to establish legal bases for processing, but Court shifted to proportionality principle to conclude that blanket online publication disproportionately interferes with fundamental rights.

holdings.direction_justification: Court restricts scope of permissible online publication of personal data, requiring proportionality assessment that favors privacy over transparency.

balancing.necessity_summary: Court applied strict necessity standard, requiring that objectives cannot reasonably be achieved just as effectively by other less restrictive means, and found blanket publication fails this test.
balancing.balance_summary: Data subject's privacy interests outweigh the public interest in online publication of detailed personal information about family members and transactions.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection rights prevail over anti-corruption transparency objectives where publication includes sensitive personal details about family members and financial transactions.

holdings.core_holding: Personal data liable to indirectly reveal sexual orientation constitutes processing of special categories of personal data under Article 9(1) GDPR.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 8(1) of Directive 95/46 states that Member States are to prohibit the processing of personal data 'revealing' racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, and the processing of data 'concerning' health or sex life.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Such an interpretation, which would result in a distinction being drawn according to the type of sensitive data at issue, would not, however, be consistent with a contextual analysis of those provisions, in particular with Article 4(15) of the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Furthermore, a wide interpretation of the terms 'special categories of personal data' and 'sensitive data' is confirmed by the objective of Directive 95/46 and the GDPR, noted in paragraph 61 of the present judgment, which is to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular of their private life, with respect to the processing of personal data concerning them.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 8(1) of Directive 95/46 and Article 9(1) of the GDPR provide for the prohibition, inter alia, of processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The contrary interpretation would, moreover, run counter to the purpose of Article 8(1) of Directive 95/46 and Article 9(1) of the GDPR, namely to ensure enhanced protection as regards processing which, because of the particular sensitivity of the data processed, is liable to constitute, as follows from recital 33 of Directive 95/46 and recital 51 of the GDPR, a particularly serious interference with the fundamental rights.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Consequently, those provisions cannot be interpreted as meaning that the processing of personal data that are liable indirectly to reveal sensitive information concerning a natural person is excluded from the strengthened protection regime prescribed by those provisions, if the effectiveness of that regime and the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons that it is intended to ensure are not to be compromised.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of special categories to include indirect revelation of sensitive data expands protection for data subjects.

holdings.core_holding: Directive 2017/1132 does not oblige Member States to permit disclosure of personal data in company constitutive instruments beyond minimum required data.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Having regard in particular to the repeated use of the term 'translations' in Article 21(2) of Directive 2017/1132, it is apparent from the wording of that provision that it concerns the voluntary disclosure of translations of the documents and particulars referred to in Article 14 of that directive into an official language of the European Union and, therefore, only the language of in which those documents and particulars are published.
interpretation.systematic_quote: As regards the context of Article 21(2) of Directive 2017/1132, the title of that article, which refers to the 'Language of disclosure and translation of documents and particulars to be disclosed', as well as the other paragraphs of that article, support the interpretation referred to in paragraph 55 of this judgment.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Last, the interpretation referred to in paragraph 55 of this judgment is confirmed by recital 12 thereof, according to which cross-border access to company information should be facilitated by allowing, in addition to compulsory disclosure made in one of the languages permitted in the company's Member State, the voluntary registration in additional languages of the required documents and particulars.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Where the meaning of a provision of EU law is absolutely plain from its very wording, the Court cannot depart from that interpretation.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Where the meaning of a provision of EU law is absolutely plain from its very wording, the Court cannot depart from that interpretation (judgment of 25 January 2022, VYSOČINA WIND, C-181/20, EU:C:2022:51, paragraph 39).

holdings.direction_justification: This holding clarifies scope of EU directive without expanding or restricting data subject rights.

holdings.core_holding: The authority maintaining the commercial register is both a recipient and controller of personal data it publishes, even for non-required data.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under Article 4(7) of the GDPR, the concept of 'controller' covers natural or legal persons, public authorities, agencies or other bodies which, alone or jointly with others, determine the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It follows from Article 2(d) that the controller is the entity which 'determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In that regard, it should be borne in mind that, according to the case-law of the Court, that provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: By transcribing and storing personal data received in connection with an application for registration of a company in the commercial register of a Member State, by disclosing those data, where appropriate, on request to third parties and publishing them in the national gazette, or by an equally effective means, the authority responsible for maintaining that register carries out processing of personal data for which it is the 'controller', within the meaning of Article 4(2) and (7) of the GDPR.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held that it would be contrary to the objective of Article 4(7) of the GDPR, referred to in paragraph 72 of the present judgment, to exclude the Official Journal of a Member State from the concept of 'controller' on the ground that it does not review the personal data contained in its publications.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: That provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition ensures commercial register authority bears GDPR obligations for all published data.

holdings.core_holding: A Member State cannot refuse erasure requests for non-required personal data solely because redacted document copies were not provided by the applicant.

interpretation.semantic_quote: In accordance with Article 17(1) of the GDPR, the data subject has the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay and the controller has the obligation to erase those personal data without undue delay where one of the grounds set out in that provision applies.
interpretation.systematic_quote: In accordance with Article 161 of that directive, the processing of personal data carried out in the context of that directive must fully satisfy the requirements arising from the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: It is thus for the Member States, in the context of the implementation of the obligations imposed by that directive, to ensure that the objectives of legal certainty and protection of the interests of third parties pursued by that directive and recalled in paragraph 77 of the present judgment, are reconciled with the rights enshrined in the GDPR and the fundamental right to the protection of personal data, by striking a fair balance between those objectives and those rights.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from that latter provision, read in conjunction with Article 21(1) of the GDPR, that the data subject enjoys a right to object to processing and a right to erasure, unless there are overriding legitimate grounds which take precedence over the interests and rights and freedoms of that person within the meaning of Article 21(1) of the GDPR, which it is for the controller to demonstrate.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held that the activity of a public authority consisting in safeguarding, in a database, data which companies are required to communicate on the basis of legal obligations, permitting interested persons to consult those data and providing them with copies thereof, falls within the exercise of public powers and constitutes a task carried out in the public interest within the meaning of that provision.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: It is thus for the Member States to ensure that the objectives of legal certainty and protection of the interests of third parties pursued by that directive are reconciled with the rights enshrined in the GDPR and the fundamental right to the protection of personal data, by striking a fair balance between those objectives and those rights.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of national law allowed refusal of erasure requests, but Court shifted to principle of effective data protection to require erasure regardless of procedural non-compliance.

holdings.direction_justification: Data subjects can obtain erasure of non-required personal data from commercial registers without needing third-party cooperation.

balancing.necessity_summary: Making non-required personal data publicly available online was not strictly necessary to achieve the public interest objectives of the commercial register disclosure requirements.
balancing.balance_summary: Data subject's right to erasure prevails over administrative convenience and procedural requirements imposed by national law.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection prevails over interests of legal certainty and third-party protection regarding non-required personal data in commercial registers.

holdings.core_holding: A handwritten signature of a natural person constitutes personal data under the GDPR.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That provision lays down that personal data means 'any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person' and specifies that 'an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In that connection, the Court has already held that the use of the expression 'any information' in the definition of the concept of 'personal data' in that provision reflects the aim of the EU legislature to assign a wide scope to that concept, which potentially encompasses all kinds of information, not only objective but also subjective, in the form of opinions and assessments, provided that it 'relates' to the data subject.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It also follows from the case-law of the Court that the handwriting of a natural person provides information relating to that person.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It also follows from the case-law of the Court that the handwriting of a natural person provides information relating to that person (see, to that effect, judgment of 20 December 2017, Nowak, C-434/16, EU:C:2017:994, paragraph 37).

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data to include handwritten signatures expands scope of GDPR protection.

holdings.core_holding: Loss of control over personal data for a limited period may constitute compensable non-material damage if the data subject proves actual damage occurred.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That provision states that 'any person who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of [the GDPR] shall have the right to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: It is apparent not only from the wording of Article 82(1) of the GDPR, read in the light of recitals 85 and 146 thereof – which encourage the acceptance of a broad interpretation of the concept of 'non-material damage', within the meaning of that first provision – but also from the objective of ensuring a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data – which is referred to by the regulation – that the fear experienced by a data subject with regard to a possible misuse of his or her personal data by third parties as a result of an infringement of that regulation is capable, in itself, of constituting 'non-material damage', within the meaning of Article 82(1).

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 82(1) of the GDPR must be interpreted as meaning that the mere infringement of that regulation is not sufficient to confer a right to compensation, since the existence of 'damage', material or non-material, or of 'damage' which has been 'suffered' constitutes one of the conditions for the right to compensation laid down in Article 82(1).
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, it is apparent from the illustrative list of types of 'damage' that may be suffered by data subjects, set out in the first sentence of recital 85 of the GDPR, that the EU legislature intended to include in the concept of 'damage' that may be suffered by data subjects, inter alia, the mere 'loss of control' over their own personal data, as a result of an infringement of that regulation, even if there had been no actual misuse of the data in question.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The right to compensation laid down in Article 82(1), in particular in the case of non-material damage, fulfils an exclusively compensatory function, in that financial compensation based on that provision must allow the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in full, and not a deterrent or punitive function.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

holdings.core_holding: A non-binding supervisory authority opinion cannot exempt the controller from liability under Article 82(3) GDPR.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 82(3) of the GDPR, for its part, states that a controller is to be exempt from liability under paragraph 2 if it proves that it is not in any way responsible for the event giving rise to the damage.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Among the powers listed in Article 58(3) of the GDPR is included, in point (b) of that provision, the power 'to issue, on its own initiative or on request, opinions to the national parliament, the Member State government or, in accordance with Member State law, to other institutions and bodies as well as to the public on any issue related to the protection of personal data'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Such an interpretation of Article 82(3) is also consistent with the objectives pursued by the GDPR of ensuring a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data and of ensuring effective compensation for the damage that they may suffer as a result of processing of those data that infringes that regulation.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Since an opinion issued to the controller is not legally binding, it cannot in itself demonstrate that that the damage is not attributable to that controller, within the meaning of the case-law cited in paragraph 164 of the present judgment, nor, therefore, that it is sufficient to exempt that controller from liability under Article 82(3) of the GDPR.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, it follows from a combined analysis of Article 82(1) to (3) of the GDPR, the context of that article and the objectives pursued by the EU legislature by means of that regulation that that article provides for fault-based liability in which the burden of proof rests not on the person who has suffered damage, but on the controller.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: If it were sufficient for the controller to rely on a legally non-binding opinion in order to escape all liability and, accordingly, from any obligation to compensate, the controller would not be encouraged to do everything within its power to ensure that high level of protection and to comply with the obligations imposed by that regulation.

holdings.direction_justification: Controllers cannot escape liability by relying on DPA opinions, maintaining strong accountability standards.

holdings.core_holding: In automated decision-making including profiling, data subjects may require controllers to explain in a concise, transparent, and intelligible form the procedure and principles actually applied to their personal data.

interpretation.semantic_quote: The generally accepted meanings of the concept of 'meaningful information' under that provision, in the various language versions of that provision, differ; some, like the French-language version, favour the functionality ('nuttige' in Dutch, 'úteis' in Portuguese) or the relevance ('pertinente' in Romanian) of the information to be provided, while others place greater emphasis on the importance of that information ('significativa' in Spanish and 'istotne' in Polish).
interpretation.systematic_quote: Having regard to the fact that the concept of 'meaningful information about the logic involved' also appears in Article 13(2)(f) and Article 14(2)(g) of the GDPR, the Court has already held that, in the case of automated decision-making, within the meaning of Article 22(1) of that regulation, the right of access to such information enshrined in Article 15(1)(h) thereof forms a whole with the additional information obligations imposed on the controller under Article 13(2)(f) and Article 14(2)(g) of the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That right of access is necessary to enable the data subject to exercise, depending on the circumstances, his or her right to rectification, right to erasure ('right to be forgotten') or right to restriction of processing, conferred, respectively, by Articles 16, 17 and 18 of the GDPR, as well as the data subject's right to object to his or her personal data being processed, laid down in Article 21 of the GDPR, right of action and right to compensation, laid down in Articles 79 and 82 of the GDPR, respectively.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It must therefore be held that the wording of Article 15(1)(h) of the GDPR covers all relevant information concerning the procedure and principles relating to the use, by automated means, of personal data with a view to obtaining a specific result.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As regards, specifically, the right of access provided for in Article 15 of the GDPR, it is apparent from the case-law of the Court that that right must enable the data subject to ensure that the personal data concerning him or her are correct and that they are processed in a lawful manner.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: If the individuals affected by an automated decision, including profiling, were not in a position to understand the reasons which led to that decision before expressing their point of view or contesting the decision, those rights would not, accordingly, satisfy in full their purpose of protecting those individuals against the particular risks to their rights and freedoms represented by the automated processing of their personal data.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of meaningful information requires controllers to explain procedure and principles of automated processing, enhancing data subject understanding and ability to exercise rights.

holdings.core_holding: When information under Article 15(1)(h) contains third-party data or trade secrets, the controller must provide it to the supervisory authority or court to balance competing interests.

interpretation.systematic_quote: Moreover, recital 63 of that regulation states that the right for any data subject to have access to personal data which have been collected concerning him or her should not adversely affect the rights or freedoms of others, including trade secrets or intellectual property and in particular the copyright protecting the software.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In the event of conflict between, on the one hand, exercising the right of full and complete access to personal data and, on the other hand, the rights or freedoms of others, a balance will have to be struck between the rights and freedoms in question.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: However, the result of those considerations should not be a refusal to provide all information to the data subject.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Advocate General observed in point 94 of his Opinion, that case-law can be fully transposed to the situation in which the information to be provided to the data subject under the right of access guaranteed by Article 15(1)(h) of the GDPR is likely to result in an infringement of the rights and freedoms of others, in particular in so far as it contains personal data of third parties protected by that regulation or trade secrets, within the meaning of point 1 of Article 2 of Directive 2016/943.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: In that regard, it should be borne in mind that a Member State cannot definitively prescribe the result of a case-by-case balancing of the rights and interests at issue imposed by EU law.

holdings.direction_justification: Balances data subject access rights against trade secrets and third-party rights, requiring case-by-case assessment rather than blanket exclusions; invalidates Austrian provision creating automatic exception.

balancing.necessity_summary: Court applies necessity requirement from Article 23(1)(i), holding restrictions must be necessary and proportionate, precluding blanket national exclusions for trade secrets.
other_rights: rights and freedoms of third parties
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Neither right automatically prevails; case-by-case balancing by supervisory authority or court is required, with partial disclosure being a possible middle ground.

holdings.core_holding: Processing of biometric and genetic data by police is authorized by Member State law if that law contains a sufficiently clear and precise legal basis, even if it incorrectly references the GDPR instead of Directive 2016/680.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It follows from the case-law recalled in the previous paragraph of the present judgment that there can be no uncertainty as to the provisions of EU law pursuant to which national law may authorise processing of biometric and genetic data, such as the processing at issue in the main proceedings, or as to the applicable conditions governing that authorisation.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Whilst the national legislature has the option to provide, in the same legislative instrument, for the processing of personal data for purposes covered by Directive 2016/680 and for other purposes covered by the GDPR, it has, on the other hand, the obligation, in accordance with the requirements set out in the previous paragraph of the present judgment, to make sure that there is no ambiguity as to the applicability of one or other of those two EU acts to the collection of biometric and genetic data.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Data subjects and the courts having jurisdiction must be in a position to be able to determine precisely, in particular, the conditions under which that processing may take place and the purposes which it may lawfully pursue.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: The legal basis authorising such a limitation must define the scope of that limitation sufficiently clearly and precisely.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In that regard, it is clear from the Court's case-law that that requirement means that the legal basis authorising such a limitation must define the scope of that limitation sufficiently clearly and precisely.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding clarifies technical transposition requirements without expanding or restricting substantive data protection rights.

holdings.core_holding: National legislation may allow courts to authorize compulsory collection of biometric and genetic data from accused persons without assessing evidence, provided effective judicial review is subsequently guaranteed.

interpretation.semantic_quote: The existence of sufficient items of evidence pointing to a person's guilt constitutes, in principle, a serious ground for believing that he or she has committed the offence at issue.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 6 of Directive 2016/680 obliges the Member States to provide for the controller, 'where applicable and as far as possible', to make a clear distinction between personal data of different categories of data subjects.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Such collection may contribute to the objective set out in recital 27 of Directive 2016/680, which states that, for the prevention, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences, it is necessary for competent authorities to process personal data collected in the context of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of specific criminal offences beyond that context in order to develop an understanding of criminal activities and to make links between different criminal offences detected.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows that Article 6(a) of Directive 2016/680 does not preclude national legislation which provides for the compulsory collection, in order to be entered in a record, of biometric and genetic data concerning persons in respect of whom sufficient evidence is gathered that they are guilty of an intentional offence subject to public prosecution and who have been accused for that reason.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, the protection of personal data resulting from the explicit obligation laid down in Article 8(1) of the Charter is especially important for the right to respect for private life.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Observance of the right to be presumed innocent requires that court to be free of any bias and any prejudice when it carries out that examination.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding permits compulsory data collection without full judicial review at the initial stage, favoring law enforcement operational needs over immediate data subject protection.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court found that limiting judicial review at the preliminary criminal procedure stage may be justified where it might impede criminal investigations, provided subsequent effective review is guaranteed.
balancing.balance_summary: Law enforcement interests in effective criminal investigation temporarily outweigh data subject's right to immediate full judicial review, subject to subsequent review guarantees.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Both rights are accommodated: presumption of innocence is preserved because the court does not assess guilt, and effective judicial protection is ensured through subsequent review mechanisms.

holdings.core_holding: National legislation providing for systematic collection of biometric and genetic data of all persons accused of intentional public prosecution offences is precluded without verification that collection is strictly necessary.

interpretation.semantic_quote: As is set out in Article 10 of Directive 2016/680, the requirement that the processing of such data be allowed 'only where strictly necessary' must be interpreted as establishing strengthened conditions for lawful processing of sensitive data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The specific requirements of Article 10 of Directive 2016/680 constitute a special form of implementation, applicable to certain categories of data, of the principles set out in Articles 4 and 8 of that directive, which must be observed by any data processing falling within the directive's scope.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The purpose of that article is to ensure enhanced protection with regard to that processing, which, because of the particular sensitivity of the data at issue and the context in which they are processed, is liable, as is apparent from recital 37 of the directive, to create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It must be held that national legislation which provides for the systematic collection of the biometric and genetic data of any person accused of an intentional offence subject to public prosecution is, in principle, contrary to the requirement laid down in Article 10 of Directive 2016/680 that processing of the special categories of data referred to in that article is to be allowed 'only where strictly necessary'.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In that regard, first, it must be borne in mind, as is apparent from recital 26 of Directive 2016/680, that the requirement of necessity is met where the objective pursued by the data processing at issue cannot reasonably be achieved just as effectively by other means less restrictive of the fundamental rights of data subjects.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: In view of the foregoing, it must be held that national legislation which provides for the systematic collection of the biometric and genetic data of any person accused of an intentional offence subject to public prosecution is, in principle, contrary to the requirement laid down in Article 10 of Directive 2016/680.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding prohibits systematic blanket collection of sensitive biometric and genetic data, requiring individualized necessity assessment and limiting law enforcement discretion.

balancing.necessity_summary: Article 10 requires processing of sensitive data to be allowed only where strictly necessary, establishing a heightened standard requiring particularly rigorous assessment compared to ordinary necessity.
balancing.balance_summary: Data subject's fundamental rights to privacy and data protection prevail over generalized law enforcement interests in systematic biometric data collection.
other_rights: right to respect for private life
right to protection of personal data
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Enhanced protection of sensitive biometric and genetic data prevails, requiring individualized strict necessity assessment rather than blanket collection for crime prevention purposes.

holdings.core_holding: An official journal may be classified as a controller of personal data in published documents even without legal personality, where national law determines the purposes and means of processing.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under point 7 of Article 4 of the GDPR, the concept of 'controller' covers natural or legal persons, public authorities, agencies or other bodies which, alone or jointly with others, determine the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is apparent from the clear wording of that provision that a controller may be not only a natural or legal person, but also a public authority, an agency or a body, and such entities do not necessarily have legal personality under national law.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In that regard, it should be borne in mind that, according to the case-law of the Court, that provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Having regard to the wording of point 7 of Article 4 of the GDPR, read in the light of that objective, it appears that, in order to establish whether a person or entity is to be classified as a 'controller' within the meaning of that provision, it must be examined whether that person or entity determines, alone or jointly with others, the purposes and means of the processing or whether those purposes and means are determined by national law.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In that regard, it should be borne in mind that, according to the case-law of the Court, that provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.
