reasoning.principle_based_quote: Moreover, it would be contrary to the objective of point 7 of Article 4 of the GDPR, referred to in paragraph 28 of the present judgment, to exclude the official journal of a Member State from the concept of 'controller' on the ground that it does not exercise control over the personal data contained in its publications.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition to include official journals ensures data subjects can exercise their rights against the publishing entity.

holdings.core_holding: The official journal is solely responsible for compliance with Article 5(1) principles for its processing operations unless national law establishes joint responsibility with other entities in the processing chain.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under Article 5(2) of the GDPR, the controller is to be responsible for compliance with the principles laid down in the form of obligations in paragraph 1 of that article and must be able to demonstrate compliance with those principles.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is thus apparent from that provision that the respective responsibilities of joint controllers of personal data do not necessarily depend on the existence of an arrangement between the various controllers, but may stem from national law.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In that regard, it should be borne in mind that, according to the case-law of the Court, that provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Therefore, the Moniteur belge must be considered to be responsible, under Article 5(2) of the GDPR, for compliance with the principles set out in paragraph 1 of that article, as regards the processing that it is required to perform under national law, and, accordingly, with all the obligations imposed on the controller by the GDPR.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has held, first, that it is sufficient that a person exerts influence over the processing of personal data, for his, her or its own purposes, and participates, as a result, in the determination of the purposes and means of that processing in order for him, her or it to be regarded as a joint controller.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding clarifies allocation of responsibility without expanding or restricting either controller obligations or data subject rights.

holdings.core_holding: Courts making documents containing personal data available to journalists for reporting falls within their judicial capacity, excluding DPA supervisory competence.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It is apparent from Article 55 of Regulation 2016/679 that the purpose of that article is to define competence in matters of supervision of the processing of personal data and, in particular, to delimit the competence vested in the national supervisory authority.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Regulation 2016/679 can be distinguished in that regard from Directive 2003/4/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 28 January 2003 on public access to environmental information and repealing Council Directive 90/313/EEC, which does not apply to courts and tribunals.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Recital 20 of Regulation 2016/679, in the light of which that Article 55(3) must be read, states that it should be possible to entrust supervision of processing operations carried out by the courts 'acting in their judicial capacity' to specific bodies within the judicial system of the Member State concerned rather than to the supervisory authority under the authority of that Member State, in order to 'safeguard the independence of the judiciary in the performance of its judicial tasks, including decision-making'.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 55(3) of Regulation 2016/679 thus provides that processing operations carried out by courts 'acting in their judicial capacity' fall outside the competence of that supervisory authority.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Safeguarding the independence of the judiciary presupposes, in general, that judicial functions are exercised wholly autonomously, without the courts being subject to any hierarchical constraint or subordinate relationship and without taking orders or instructions from any source whatsoever, thus being protected from any external intervention or pressure liable to jeopardise the independent judgment of their members and to influence their decisions.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Observance of the guarantees of independence and impartiality necessary under EU law requires rules in order to dispel any reasonable doubt in the minds of individuals as to the imperviousness of the body in question to external factors and its neutrality with respect to the interests concerned.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of Article 55(3) refers to courts acting in judicial capacity; Court shifted to principle of judicial independence to interpret this broadly to include communication activities like sharing documents with journalists.

holdings.direction_justification: Court interprets judicial capacity exception broadly to exclude DPA oversight, limiting data subjects' ability to complain to supervisory authority about court data processing.

balancing.rights_balance_summary: Judicial independence prevails over data protection supervision; courts' communication activities for transparency are shielded from DPA oversight.

holdings.core_holding: A national authority keeping a public register must rectify personal data relating to gender identity where those data are inaccurate under the accuracy principle.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under Article 16 of the GDPR, the data subject has the right to obtain from the controller without undue delay the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her.
interpretation.systematic_quote: That provision gives specific expression to the fundamental right enshrined in the second sentence of Article 8(2) of the Charter, according to which everyone has the right of access to data which have been collected concerning him or her, and the right to have them rectified.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The objective pursued by that regulation, as is set out in Article 1 thereof and in recitals 1 and 10 thereof, consists, inter alia, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It is apparent from the third sentence of recital 10 of that regulation that those specific provisions are intended only to further specify the application of the rules contained in the GDPR, and not to derogate from them.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In that regard, it must be noted that, according to the case-law of the Court, the assessment of whether personal data is accurate and complete must be made in the light of the purpose for which those data were collected.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: A Member State cannot rely on the absence, in its national law, of a procedure for the legal recognition of transgender identity in order to limit the right to rectification.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of Article 6(2)-(3) could allow Member State specificity, but Court shifted to fundamental rights principle (Article 8 Charter) to conclude such provisions cannot limit the right to rectification.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of rectification right prevents Member States from limiting gender identity rectification through absence of national procedures.

other_rights: right to integrity of the person
right to respect for private life
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection right to rectification prevails alongside Articles 3 and 7 Charter rights, requiring Member States to allow gender identity rectification regardless of national law gaps.

holdings.core_holding: Member States cannot require proof of gender reassignment surgery as condition for exercising the right to rectification of gender identity data in public registers.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 16 of the GDPR does not specify which evidence may be required by a controller in order to establish the inaccuracy of the personal data which a natural person seeks to have rectified.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 23(1) of the GDPR provides that EU or Member State law to which the data controller or processor is subject may restrict by way of a legislative measure the scope of the obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Such an administrative practice undermines the essence of the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Charter and, in particular, the essence of the right to the integrity of the person and the right to respect for private life, referred to in Articles 3 and 7 of the Charter respectively.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: First, it must be noted that that administrative practice does not satisfy the requirement that a Member State's law may restrict the scope of the right provided for in Article 16 of the GDPR only by means of legislative measures.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It is apparent from the settled case-law of the European Court of Human Rights that Article 8 ECHR, which corresponds to Article 7 of the Charter, protects a person's gender identity, which is a constituent element and one of the most intimate aspects of their private life.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Article 8 imposes positive obligations on States, in addition to negative obligations to protect transgender persons against arbitrary interference by public authorities, which also entails the establishment of effective and accessible procedures guaranteeing effective respect for their right to gender identity.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Article 23 text permits restrictions via legislative measures for public register reliability, but Court shifted to fundamental rights principles (essence of Articles 3 and 7 Charter) to conclude surgery requirement is impermissible under any circumstances.

holdings.direction_justification: Prohibits surgery requirement for gender identity rectification, protecting transgender persons from disproportionate evidentiary burdens.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court applied strict necessity, finding that requiring gender reassignment surgery is neither necessary nor proportionate to ensure public register reliability when medical certificates suffice.
other_rights: right to integrity of the person
right to respect for private life
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Right to rectification prevails alongside bodily integrity and privacy rights, as surgery requirements violate the essence of these fundamental rights.

holdings.core_holding: A national competition authority may find that a dominant undertaking's data processing terms are inconsistent with the GDPR when necessary to establish abuse of dominance, subject to sincere cooperation with data protection supervisory authorities.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Neither the GDPR nor any other instrument of EU law provides for specific rules on cooperation between a national competition authority and the relevant national supervisory authorities concerned or the lead supervisory authority.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The supervisory authorities, on the one hand, and the national competition authorities, on the other, perform different functions and pursue their own objectives and tasks.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Excluding the rules on the protection of personal data from the legal framework to be taken into consideration by the competition authorities when examining an abuse of a dominant position would disregard the reality of this economic development and would be liable to undermine the effectiveness of competition law within the European Union.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 55(1) of the GDPR states the general rule that each supervisory authority is to be competent for the performance of the tasks assigned to it and the exercise of the powers conferred on it, in accordance with that regulation, on the territory of its own Member State.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Under that principle, in accordance with settled case-law, in areas covered by EU law, Member States, including their administrative authorities, must assist each other, in full mutual respect, in carrying out tasks which flow from the Treaties.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: When national competition authorities are called upon, in the exercise of their powers, to examine whether an undertaking's conduct is consistent with the provisions of the GDPR, they are required to consult and cooperate sincerely with the national supervisory authorities concerned or with the lead supervisory authority.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding addresses institutional competence allocation between competition and data protection authorities, not substantive rights of data subjects or controllers.

holdings.core_holding: Collection and linking of off-platform data revealing sensitive categories constitutes prohibited processing of special categories of personal data, regardless of whether the revealed information concerns the user or another person.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 9(1) of the GDPR lays down the principle that the processing of special categories of personal data listed therein is prohibited.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Recital 51 of the GDPR states that personal data which are, by their nature, particularly sensitive in relation to fundamental rights and freedoms merit specific protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to the fundamental rights and freedoms.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In view of the significant risks to the fundamental freedoms and fundamental rights of data subjects arising from any processing of personal data falling within the categories referred to in Article 9(1) of the GDPR, the objective thereof is to prohibit such processing, irrespective of its stated purpose.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: For the purposes of applying Article 9(1) of the GDPR, it is important to determine, where personal data is processed by the operator of an online social network, if those data allow information falling within one of the categories referred to in that provision to be revealed.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: That fundamental prohibition, laid down in Article 9(1) of the GDPR, is independent of whether or not the information revealed by the processing operation in question is correct and of whether the controller is acting with the aim of obtaining information that falls within one of the special categories referred to in that provision.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of special categories to include data that can reveal sensitive information extends protection to users whose browsing behavior may reveal health, political, or sexual orientation data.

holdings.core_holding: Merely visiting websites does not constitute manifestly making data public; entering information or clicking buttons only does so where the user explicitly chose to make data accessible to an unlimited number of persons.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under that provision, the fundamental prohibition of any processing of special categories of personal data, established in Article 9(1) of the GDPR, does not apply in the circumstance where the processing relates to personal data which are 'manifestly made public by the data subject'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In so far as it provides for an exception to the principle that the processing of special categories of personal data is prohibited, Article 9(2) of the GDPR must be interpreted strictly.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: For the purposes of the application of the exception laid down in Article 9(2)(e) of the GDPR, it is important to ascertain whether the data subject had intended, explicitly and by a clear affirmative action, to make the personal data in question accessible to the general public.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In so far as it provides for an exception to the principle that the processing of special categories of personal data is prohibited, Article 9(2) of the GDPR must be interpreted strictly.

holdings.direction_justification: Narrow interpretation of the manifestly made public exception prevents social networks from claiming user browsing or interaction implies public disclosure of sensitive data.

holdings.core_holding: Processing of off-platform data is necessary for contract performance only if objectively indispensable for a purpose integral to the contractual obligation, such that the contract's main subject matter cannot be achieved without it.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under point (b) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, that provision provides that processing of personal data is lawful if it is 'necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party or in order to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The fact that such processing may be referred to in the contract or may be merely useful for the performance of the contract is, in itself, irrelevant in that regard.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The decisive factor for the purposes of applying the justification set out in point (b) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR is rather that the processing of personal data by the controller must be essential for the proper performance of the contract concluded between the controller and the data subject.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: In order for the processing of personal data to be regarded as necessary for the performance of a contract, within the meaning of that provision, it must be objectively indispensable for a purpose that is integral to the contractual obligation intended for the data subject.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In that context, it should be recalled that the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR sets out an exhaustive and restrictive list of the cases in which processing of personal data can be regarded as lawful.

holdings.direction_justification: Strict interpretation of contract necessity prevents social networks from bundling unnecessary data processing into service contracts and claiming contractual basis.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court applies a strict necessity test requiring that processing be objectively indispensable and that no workable, less intrusive alternatives exist for achieving the contractual purpose.

holdings.core_holding: Processing for legitimate interests requires informing users of the specific interest pursued, strict necessity, and a balancing test where users' interests and fundamental rights do not override the controller's legitimate interest.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That provision provides that the processing of personal data is lawful only if it is 'necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data, in particular where the data subject is a child'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The condition relating to the need for processing must be examined in conjunction with the 'data minimisation' principle enshrined in Article 5(1)(c) of the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In those circumstances, it must be held that the interests and fundamental rights of such a user override the interest of that operator in such personalised advertising by which it finances its activity, with the result that the processing by that operator for such purposes cannot fall within the scope of point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: As the Court has already held, that provision lays down three cumulative conditions so that the processing of personal data covered by that provision is lawful.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, that provision lays down three cumulative conditions so that the processing of personal data covered by that provision is lawful, namely, first, the pursuit of a legitimate interest by the data controller or by a third party; second, the need to process personal data for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued; and third, that the interests or fundamental freedoms and rights of the person concerned by the data protection do not take precedence over the legitimate interest of the controller or of a third party.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Despite the fact that the services of an online social network such as Facebook are free of charge, the user of that network cannot reasonably expect that the operator of the social network will process that user's personal data, without his or her consent, for the purposes of personalised advertising.

holdings.direction_justification: Users' fundamental rights and reasonable expectations override controller's advertising interests; extensive tracking creates a feeling of continuous surveillance that overrides commercial interests.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court requires strict necessity showing the legitimate interest cannot be achieved by less restrictive means, combined with the data minimisation principle.
balancing.balance_summary: User fundamental rights and lack of reasonable expectation of personalised advertising processing override the operator's commercial interest in advertising-funded services.
other_rights: right to respect for private life
right to protection of personal data
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection rights under Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter prevail over the controller's interest in personalised advertising that finances its commercial activity.

holdings.core_holding: Processing for legal obligation compliance requires actual necessity pursuant to EU or Member State law meeting a public interest objective, proportionality to the legitimate aim, and strict necessity in the processing carried out.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under point (c), processing of personal data is lawful if it is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR specifies, inter alia, in respect of those two situations in which processing is lawful, that the processing must be based on EU law or on Member State law to which the controller is subject.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That legal basis must meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Under point (c), processing of personal data is lawful if it is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding provides interpretive guidance on the legal obligation basis without decisively expanding or limiting its scope.

balancing.necessity_summary: Processing must be strictly necessary for compliance with an actual legal obligation under EU or Member State law meeting proportionality requirements.

holdings.core_holding: A social network operator cannot in principle rely on vital interests or public interest/official authority bases to justify off-platform data collection given its essentially commercial nature.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That provision provides that the processing of personal data is lawful where it is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of another natural person.
interpretation.systematic_quote: As can be seen from recital 46 of that regulation, that provision covers the specific situation in which the processing of personal data is necessary to protect an interest which is essential for the life of the data subject or that of another natural person.
interpretation.teleological_quote: It follows from those examples and from the strict interpretation to be given to point (d) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR that, in view of the nature of the services provided by the operator of an online social network, such an operator, whose activity is essentially economic and commercial in nature, cannot rely on the protection of an interest which is essential for the life of its users or of another person in order to justify, absolutely and in a purely abstract and preventive manner, the lawfulness of data processing.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Under point (d), processing that is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of another natural person is lawful.

holdings.direction_justification: Limiting commercial entities from invoking vital interests or public interest bases prevents abuse of these narrow exceptions by private platforms.

holdings.core_holding: A dominant position does not per se preclude valid consent, but is an important factor in assessing whether consent was freely given, particularly regarding imbalance of power and bundling of unnecessary processing.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 4(11) of the GDPR, for its part, defines 'consent' as meaning 'any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 7(4) of the GDPR provides that when assessing whether consent is freely given, utmost account must be taken of whether, inter alia, the performance of a contract, including the provision of a service, is conditional on consent to the processing of personal data that is not necessary for the performance of that contract.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Such a circumstance must be taken into consideration in assessing whether the user of that network has validly and, in particular, freely given consent, since that circumstance is liable to affect the freedom of choice of that user, who might be unable to refuse or withdraw consent without detriment.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Point (a) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) and Article 9(2)(a) of the GDPR require the data subject's consent for the purposes of, respectively, processing his or her personal data for one or more specific purposes and processing special categories of data referred to in Article 9(1).
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Those users must be free to refuse individually, in the context of the contractual process, to give their consent to particular data processing operations not necessary for the performance of the contract, without being obliged to refrain entirely from using the service offered by the online social network operator.

holdings.direction_justification: Dominant position does not automatically invalidate consent (pro-controller), but must be considered as important factor affecting freedom of choice and requires option to refuse without detriment (pro-data subject).

balancing.balance_summary: Clear imbalance from dominance favors imposing non-necessary conditions; users must be offered equivalent alternatives or pay-for-privacy options to ensure free consent.

holdings.core_holding: A supervisory authority decision on a complaint is subject to full judicial review, not merely procedural review of whether the complaint was handled.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That provision provides that, without prejudice to any other administrative or non-judicial remedy, each natural or legal person is to have the right to an effective judicial remedy against a legally binding decision of a supervisory authority concerning them.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is important to note that, in accordance with Article 8(3) of the Charter and Article 51(1) and Article 57(1)(a) of the GDPR, the national supervisory authorities are responsible for monitoring compliance with the EU rules concerning the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.
interpretation.teleological_quote: If Article 78(1) of that regulation were to be interpreted as meaning that the judicial review referred to therein is limited to verifying whether the supervisory authority has handled the complaint, investigated the subject matter of the complaint to the extent appropriate and informed the complainant of the outcome of the investigation, the attainment of the objectives and the pursuit of the purpose of the regulation would necessarily be compromised.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from Article 78(1) of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 143 of that regulation, that courts seised of an action against a decision of a supervisory authority should exercise full jurisdiction, which should include jurisdiction to examine all questions of fact and law relevant to the dispute before them.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Thus, the Court has already held that it follows from Article 78(1) of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 143 of that regulation, that courts seised of an action against a decision of a supervisory authority should exercise full jurisdiction, which should include jurisdiction to examine all questions of fact and law relevant to the dispute before them.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The requirement for effective judicial protection would not be met if decisions concerning the exercise by such a supervisory authority of powers of investigation or the adoption of corrective measures were subject only to limited judicial review.

holdings.direction_justification: Establishes full judicial review of DPA decisions, strengthening data subject remedies against inadequate supervisory authority responses.

holdings.core_holding: Credit agencies cannot retain insolvency discharge data beyond the public register retention period as this fails the legitimate interest balancing test.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under that provision, the processing of personal data is lawful only if and to the extent that it is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: In that context, it should also be recalled that the condition relating to the need for processing must be examined in conjunction with the 'data minimisation' principle enshrined in Article 5(1)(c) of the GDPR, in accordance with which personal data must be 'adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Moreover, as the Advocate General observed in point 75 of his Opinion, the discharge from remaining debts is intended to allow the person who benefits from it to re-enter economic life and is therefore generally of existential importance to that person.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Accordingly, that provision lays down three cumulative conditions for the processing of personal data to be lawful, namely, first, the pursuit of a legitimate interest by the data controller or by a third party; second, the need to process personal data for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued; and third, that the interests or freedoms and fundamental rights of the person concerned by the data protection do not take precedence.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As regards point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, the Court has held that that provision must be interpreted as meaning that processing can be regarded as necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, within the meaning of that provision, only if such processing is carried out in so far as is strictly necessary for the purposes of that legitimate interest.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Such data is used as a negative factor when assessing the data subject's creditworthiness and therefore constitutes sensitive information about his or her private life.

holdings.direction_justification: Limits credit agency data retention to public register period, restricting controller processing and prioritizing data subject rehabilitation interests.

balancing.necessity_summary: Processing must be strictly necessary for the legitimate interest; the Court required that legitimate interests cannot reasonably be achieved by less restrictive means, concluding credit sector interests do not justify retention beyond public register period.
balancing.balance_summary: Data subject's right to re-enter economic life after insolvency discharge overrides credit sector interest in extended data retention.
other_rights: right to respect for private life
right to protection of personal data
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection rights under Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter prevail over economic interests of credit information agencies in retaining insolvency data.

holdings.core_holding: Data subjects have the right to erasure when they object to processing and the controller cannot demonstrate overriding legitimate grounds.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That provision establishes the right to erasure of personal data where the data subject objects to the processing pursuant to Article 21(1) of the GDPR and there are no 'overriding legitimate grounds for the processing'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It follows from a combined reading of those provisions that the data subject enjoys a right to object to processing and a right to erasure, unless there are overriding legitimate grounds which take precedence over the interests and rights and freedoms of that person within the meaning of Article 21(1) of the GDPR, which it is for the controller to demonstrate.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Under the latter provision, the data subject is to have the right to object, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, at any time to processing of personal data concerning him or her which is based on point (e) or (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR.

holdings.direction_justification: Confirms erasure right when data subject objects and places burden on controller to demonstrate overriding legitimate grounds.

balancing.balance_summary: Controller bears burden to demonstrate overriding legitimate grounds; absent such proof, data subject's erasure right prevails.

holdings.core_holding: Controllers must erase unlawfully processed personal data as soon as possible without undue delay.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under Article 17(1)(d) of the GDPR, to which the referring court refers, the data subject has the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay and the controller has the obligation to erase personal data without undue delay where the personal data have been unlawfully processed.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Therefore, according to the clear wording of that provision, if the national court were to conclude from its assessment of the lawfulness of the processing of personal data at issue in the main proceedings that that processing was not lawful, it would be incumbent on the controller, in this case SCHUFA, to delete the data concerned as soon as possible.

holdings.direction_justification: Affirms immediate erasure obligation for unlawfully processed data, strengthening data subject remedies.

holdings.core_holding: Article 6(3) and (4) GDPR applies to the production in civil court proceedings of documents containing personal data originally collected for other purposes such as tax inspection.

interpretation.semantic_quote: According to Article 4(2) of that regulation, the definition of 'processing' of personal data includes any operation which is performed on personal data, whether or not by automated means, such as collection, recording, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The combined provisions of Article 6(1)(e) of the GDPR and Article 6(3) thereof therefore require there to be a legal basis – national in particular – which serves as a basis for the processing of personal data by the relevant controllers acting in the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority, such as those performed by courts acting in their judicial capacity.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Those objectives include, in accordance with Article 23(1)(f) of that regulation, 'the protection of judicial independence and judicial proceedings', which, as the European Commission noted in its written observations, must be understood as referring to the protection of the administration of justice from internal or external interference, but also to the proper administration of justice.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from Article 6(4) of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 50 thereof, that such processing is allowed provided that it is based, inter alia, on Member State law and that it constitutes a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society to safeguard one of the objectives referred to in Article 23(1) of the GDPR.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It follows that a processing operation which falls within the material scope of the GDPR includes not only the creation and maintenance of the electronic staff register (see, by analogy, judgment of 30 May 2013, Worten, C-342/12, EU:C:2013:355, paragraph 19), but also the production as evidence of a document, whether digital or physical, containing personal data, ordered by a court in the context of judicial proceedings.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding clarifies the scope of GDPR application to civil proceedings without expanding or restricting rights of either party.

balancing.necessity_summary: Processing of personal data for purposes other than original collection must be necessary and proportionate in a democratic society to safeguard objectives under Article 23(1).

holdings.core_holding: When ordering document production containing personal data, national courts must balance data subject interests against other interests, applying proportionality and data minimisation principles.

interpretation.semantic_quote: According to that data minimisation principle, personal data must be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Any processing of personal data must, subject to the derogations permitted in Article 23 thereof, observe the principles governing the processing of personal data and the rights of the person concerned set out, respectively, in Chapters II and III of that regulation.
interpretation.teleological_quote: However, as recital 4 of the GDPR states, the right to the protection of personal data is not an absolute right, but must be considered in relation to its function in society and be balanced, in accordance with the principle of proportionality, against other fundamental rights, such as the right to effective judicial protection, guaranteed in Article 47 of the Charter.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Having regard to the interests involved forms part of the examination of the necessity and proportionality of the measure, which are provided for in Article 6(3) and (4) of the GDPR and which condition the lawfulness of the personal data processing.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In particular, any processing of personal data must, first, comply with the principles set out in Article 5 of that regulation and, second, satisfy the lawfulness conditions listed in Article 6 of the same regulation (see, to that effect, judgment of 6 October 2020, La Quadrature du Net and Others, C-511/18, C-512/18 and C-520/18, EU:C:2020:791, paragraph 208 and the case-law cited).
reasoning.principle_based_quote: So far as concerns the interests involved in civil court proceedings, the national court must, as is apparent in particular from recitals 1 and 2 of the GDPR, guarantee the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data, which is a fundamental right enshrined in Article 8(1) of the Charter and in Article 16 TFEU.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of Article 5 and 6 sets framework, but Court shifts to Charter rights (Articles 7, 8, 47) and proportionality principle to conclude courts must balance competing fundamental rights.

holdings.direction_justification: Requires courts to actively consider data subject interests and apply data minimisation, including pseudonymisation and access restrictions, when ordering document production.

balancing.necessity_summary: Disclosure of personal data must be adequate and relevant for the objective pursued, and the court must consider whether less intrusive means of proof exist.
balancing.balance_summary: Data subject interests must be balanced against party interests in civil proceedings, with data minimisation and proportionality requiring consideration of less intrusive alternatives.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Neither right prevails categorically; courts must balance data protection against effective judicial protection on a case-by-case basis according to proportionality.

holdings.core_holding: A petitions committee of a federated state parliament that determines purposes and means of processing personal data is a controller under the GDPR.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 4(7) of that regulation defines the 'controller' as being the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Since Article 2(2)(a) of that regulation constitutes an exception to the very wide definition of the scope of that regulation set out in Article 2(1) of that regulation, Article 2(2)(a) must be interpreted restrictively.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That applies a fortiori with respect to Regulation 2016/679, which is based on Article 16 TFEU, which states that the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union are to lay down the rules relating to the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by, in particular, Member States when carrying out activities which fall within the scope of Union law, and the rules relating to the free movement of such data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Accordingly, the definition of the concept of 'controller' in Regulation 2016/679 is not confined to public authorities, but, as emphasised by the Czech Government, is sufficiently wide to include any body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It must be recalled that the Court has already had occasion to state, in relation to Article 3(2) of Directive 95/46, which is based on Article 100a of the EC Treaty (which became, after amendment, Article 95 EC), that recourse to that legal basis does not presuppose the existence of an actual link with free movement between Member States in every situation referred to by the measure founded on that legal base.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition to include parliamentary committees expands GDPR scope and enables data subject access rights.

holdings.core_holding: The mere infringement of GDPR provisions is not sufficient to confer a right to compensation; actual damage must be proven.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It is clear from the wording of that provision that the existence of 'damage' which has been 'suffered' constitutes one of the conditions for the right to compensation laid down in that provision, as does the existence of an infringement of the GDPR and of a causal link between that damage and that infringement, those three conditions being cumulative.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 82(2) of the GDPR, which specifies the rules on liability – the principle of which is established in paragraph 1 of that article – reproduces the three conditions necessary to give rise to the right to compensation, namely processing of personal data that infringes the provisions of the GDPR, damage suffered by the data subject, and a causal link between that unlawful processing and that damage.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It should be recalled that, according to settled case-law, the terms of a provision of EU law which makes no express reference to the law of the Member States for the purpose of determining its meaning and scope must normally be given an autonomous and uniform interpretation throughout the European Union.

holdings.direction_justification: Requires proof of actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, limiting compensation claims.

holdings.core_holding: National rules cannot make compensation for non-material damage conditional on the damage reaching a certain threshold of seriousness.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 82 of that regulation confines itself to expressly stating that not only 'material damage' but also 'non-material damage' may give rise to a right to compensation, without any reference being made to any threshold of seriousness.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The third sentence of recital 146 of the GDPR states that 'the concept of damage should be broadly interpreted in the light of the case-law of the Court of Justice in a manner which fully reflects the objectives of this Regulation'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: It would be contrary to that broad conception of 'damage', favoured by the EU legislature, if that concept were limited solely to damage of a certain degree of seriousness.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: The GDPR does not define the concept of 'damage' for the purposes of the application of this instrument.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It is apparent, in particular, from recital 10 of the GDPR that the objectives of the GDPR are, inter alia, to ensure a consistent and high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data within the European Union.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of damage concept prevents Member States from imposing seriousness thresholds that would limit compensation claims.

holdings.core_holding: National courts apply domestic rules to determine damages amounts, subject to principles of equivalence and effectiveness ensuring full and effective compensation.

interpretation.systematic_quote: In the absence of EU rules on the matter, it is for the national legal order of each Member State to establish procedural rules for actions intended to safeguard the rights of individuals, in accordance with the principle of procedural autonomy.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In that regard, in view of the compensatory function of the right to compensation under Article 82 of the GDPR, as the Advocate General pointed out, in essence, in points 39, 49 and 52 of his Opinion, financial compensation based on that provision must be regarded as 'full and effective' if it allows the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in its entirety, without there being any need, for the purposes of such compensation for the damage in its entirety, to require the payment of punitive damages.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Therefore, in the absence of rules of EU law governing the matter, it is for the legal system of each Member State to prescribe the detailed rules governing actions for safeguarding rights which individuals derive from Article 82 and, in particular, the criteria for determining the extent of the compensation payable in that context, subject to compliance with those principles of equivalence and effectiveness.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It should be recalled that, according to settled case-law, in the absence of EU rules on the matter, it is for the national legal order of each Member State to establish procedural rules for actions intended to safeguard the rights of individuals.

holdings.direction_justification: Defers to national law on quantum but requires full and effective compensation, balancing procedural autonomy with data subject protection.

holdings.core_holding: Processing of personal data in the context of organizing elections in a Member State falls within the scope of the GDPR and is not excluded by Article 2(2)(a).

interpretation.semantic_quote: It should be pointed out that that exception to the applicability of the GDPR must, like the other exceptions laid down in Article 2(2), be interpreted strictly.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It should be noted that Article 2(2)(a) of the GDPR is to be read in conjunction with Article 2(2)(b) thereof and recital 16, which states that that regulation does not apply to the processing of personal data in the context of 'activities which fall outside the scope of Union law, such as activities concerning national security' and 'activities in relation to the common foreign and security policy of the Union'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Article 2(2)(a) of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 16 thereof, is designed solely to exclude from the scope of that regulation the processing of personal data carried out by State authorities in the course of an activity which is intended to safeguard national security or of an activity which can be classified in the same category.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows that the video recording of natural persons amounts to a processing of personal data which falls, in principle, within the material scope of the GDPR.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has held, Article 2(2)(a) of the GDPR is to be read in conjunction with Article 2(2)(b) thereof and recital 16.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope includes election-related data processing, rejecting narrow national security exception.

holdings.core_holding: Competent authorities may adopt administrative measures limiting or prohibiting video recording during the vote count at polling stations in elections.

interpretation.semantic_quote: With regard more specifically to Article 6(1)(e) of the GDPR, which is specifically referred to in the request for a preliminary ruling, it follows from that provision that the processing of personal data is lawful if it is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or a task carried out in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 6(1)(e) of the GDPR must be read in conjunction with Article 6(3) thereof, which states that the basis for the processing referred to in Article 6(1)(e) is to be laid down by EU law or by Member State law to which the controller is subject.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Accordingly, it must be held that the guidelines at issue are intended, in accordance with the principle of data minimisation referred to in Article 5(1)(c) of the GDPR, to minimise the interference with the right to the protection of personal data caused by video recording the electoral process.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from Article 58(2)(f) of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 129 of that regulation, that supervisory authorities are to have, inter alia, the power to impose a temporary or definitive limitation on the processing of personal data, including a ban, and that that power is to be exercised in accordance with the principle of proportionality.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The description of Bulgarian law and of the guidelines at issue, as set out in the documents before the Court, does not make it possible to establish, subject to the matters to be verified by the referring court, that the competent Bulgarian authorities exceeded the powers available to them under Article 58(2)(f) and (3)(b) of the GDPR and, in particular, that the guidelines at issue do not comply with the principle of proportionality.

holdings.direction_justification: Confirms DPA power to restrict data processing activities to protect personal data during elections, applying data minimisation principle.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court assessed whether the limitation on video recording was proportionate, finding DPAs can limit processing to minimize interference with data protection rights while permitting observation of the vote count.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection prevails through permissible limitations on video recording while still allowing direct observation, balancing transparency against personal data protection.

holdings.core_holding: The controller must provide a data subject with a first free copy of personal data undergoing processing regardless of the reasons stated for the access request.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It must be pointed out that neither the wording of Article 12(5) of the GDPR nor that of Article 15(1) and (3) thereof make the provision, free of charge, of a first copy of personal data conditional upon data subjects putting forward reasons to justify their requests.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 12 of the GDPR thus sets out the general obligations incumbent on the controller as regards the transparency of information and communications, as well as the rules governing the exercise of the rights of the data subject.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Thirdly, regarding the objectives pursued by the GDPR, it should be noted that the purpose of that regulation, as indicated by recitals 10 and 11 thereof, is to ensure a consistent and high level of protection of natural persons within the Union, as well as to strengthen and set out in detail the rights of data subjects.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from a combined reading of Article 12(5) of the GDPR and Article 15(1) and (3) thereof that (i) the data subject has the right to obtain a first copy, free of charge, of his or her personal data undergoing processing and (ii) the controller is given the option, under certain conditions, to charge a reasonable fee taking administrative costs into account or to refuse to act on a request if it is manifestly unfounded or excessive.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As has already been held by the Court, it follows from the literal analysis of the first sentence of Article 15(3) of the GDPR that that provision confers on the data subject the right to obtain a faithful reproduction of his or her personal data, understood in a broad sense, that are subject to operations that can be classified as 'processing carried out by the controller'.

holdings.direction_justification: Strengthens right of access by confirming no justification is required for requesting a first free copy of personal data.

holdings.core_holding: National legislation cannot require data subjects to bear the costs of a first copy of personal data in order to protect the economic interests of controllers.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Indeed, Article 23(1) of the GDPR merely indicates that a legislative measure of a Member State may restrict the scope of the obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 of that regulation in so far as that measure corresponds to the rights and obligations provided for in those articles and when such a restriction respects the essence of the fundamental rights and freedoms and is a necessary and proportionate measure to safeguard, inter alia, the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Similarly, Article 23(1)(i) of that regulation recalls that a restriction of the scope of the obligations and rights provided for in, inter alia, Article 15 thereof is possible 'when such a restriction respects the essence of the fundamental rights and freedoms and is a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society to safeguard … the protection of … the rights and freedoms of others'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In those circumstances, the pursuit of the objective connected with the protection of the economic interests of persons providing treatment cannot justify a measure leading to the undermining of the right to obtain, free of charge, a first copy and, as a result, of the effectiveness of the data subject's right of access to his or her personal data undergoing processing.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Consequently, Article 23(1) of the GDPR does not exclude from its scope national legislative measures adopted prior to the entry into force of that regulation in so far as those measures satisfy the conditions laid down in that provision.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Pursuant to recital 4 of that regulation, the right to the protection of personal data is not an absolute right and must be balanced against other fundamental rights, in accordance with the principle of proportionality.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Thus, the GDPR respects all the fundamental rights and observes the freedoms and principles recognised by the Charter of Fundamental Rights, as enshrined by the Treaties.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: While Article 23(1)(i) textually allows restrictions for protecting rights of others, the Court shifted to effectiveness principle to conclude economic interests cannot justify undermining access rights.

holdings.direction_justification: Limits Member State discretion to restrict right of access and rejects economic interests of controllers as valid justification.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court assessed whether charging for first copies is a necessary and proportionate measure; concluded protecting economic interests cannot justify undermining the effectiveness of access rights.
balancing.balance_summary: The economic interest of controllers in being relieved of costs cannot override the data subject's right to a first free copy of personal data.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection right to free first copy prevails over the controller's economic interests and freedom to conduct business.

holdings.core_holding: The right to a copy of personal data in medical records includes full copies of documents when necessary to ensure data are faithful, intelligible, and verifiable.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Next, the first sentence of Article 15(3) of the GDPR cannot be interpreted as establishing a separate right from that provided for in Article 15(1) thereof.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Furthermore, the term 'copy' does not relate to a document as such, but to the personal data which it contains and which must be complete.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Lastly, regarding the objectives pursued by Article 15 of the GDPR, the purpose of that regulation is to strengthen and set out in detail the rights of data subjects.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: The copy must therefore contain all the personal data undergoing processing.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has held that, according to its wording, the first sentence of Article 15(3) of the GDPR confers on the data subject the right to obtain a faithful reproduction of his or her personal data, understood in a broad sense, that are subject to operations that can be classified as 'processing' carried out by the controller.

holdings.direction_justification: Expands scope of copy right to include full document copies when necessary for intelligibility, especially for sensitive health data.

holdings.core_holding: The GDPR applies to commercial data transfers to third countries even when data may subsequently be processed by third country authorities for national security purposes.

interpretation.semantic_quote: "The operation of having personal data transferred from a Member State to a third country constitutes, in itself, processing of personal data within the meaning of Article 4(2) of the GDPR, carried out in a Member State, and falls within the scope of that regulation under Article 2(1) thereof."
interpretation.systematic_quote: "By expressly requiring the Commission, when assessing the adequacy of the level of protection afforded by a third country, to take account, inter alia, of 'relevant legislation, both general and sectoral, including concerning public security, defence, national security and criminal law and the access of public authorities to personal data', it is patent from the very wording of Article 45(2)(a) of that regulation that no processing by a third country of personal data for the purposes of public security, defence and State security excludes the transfer at issue from the application of the regulation."
interpretation.teleological_quote: "The possibility that the personal data transferred between two economic operators for commercial purposes might undergo, at the time of the transfer or thereafter, processing for the purposes of public security, defence and State security by the authorities of that third country cannot remove that transfer from the scope of the GDPR."

reasoning.rule_based_quote: "It follows that the operation of having personal data transferred from a Member State to a third country constitutes, in itself, processing of personal data within the meaning of Article 4(2) of the GDPR, carried out in a Member State, and falls within the scope of that regulation under Article 2(1) thereof."
reasoning.case_law_quote: "As the Court has already held, the protection of personal data resulting from the explicit obligation laid down in Article 8(1) of the Charter is especially important for the right to respect for private life."

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope ensures data protection continues to apply even when data may be accessed by foreign governments.

holdings.core_holding: Standard contractual clauses must ensure a level of protection essentially equivalent to that guaranteed within the EU by the GDPR read in light of the Charter.

interpretation.semantic_quote: "Article 46 of the GDPR does not specify the nature of the requirements which flow from that reference to 'appropriate safeguards', 'enforceable rights' and 'effective legal remedies'."
interpretation.systematic_quote: "That article appears in Chapter V of that regulation and, accordingly, must be read in the light of Article 44 of that regulation, entitled 'General principle for transfers', which lays down that 'all provisions [in that chapter] shall be applied in order to ensure that the level of protection of natural persons guaranteed by [that regulation] is not undermined'."
interpretation.teleological_quote: "The provisions of Chapter V of the GDPR are intended to ensure the continuity of that high level of protection where personal data is transferred to a third country, in accordance with the objective set out in recital 6 thereof."

reasoning.rule_based_quote: "In the absence of an adequacy decision under Article 45(3) of that regulation, a controller or processor may transfer personal data to a third country only if the controller or processor has provided 'appropriate safeguards', and on condition that 'enforceable data subject rights and effective legal remedies for data subjects' are available."
reasoning.case_law_quote: "The term 'adequate level of protection' must, as confirmed by recital 104 of that regulation, be understood as requiring the third country in fact to ensure, by reason of its domestic law or its international commitments, a level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms that is essentially equivalent to that guaranteed within the European Union."
reasoning.principle_based_quote: "The level of protection of fundamental rights required by Article 46(1) of that regulation must be determined on the basis of the provisions of that regulation, read in the light of the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter."

holdings.direction_justification: Imposes high standard of essentially equivalent protection for international transfers, requiring assessment of third country legal systems.

balancing.rights_balance_summary: EU fundamental rights standard applies to assess adequacy of protection in third country transfers.

holdings.core_holding: Supervisory authorities must suspend or prohibit transfers to third countries when standard clauses cannot be complied with and protection cannot be ensured by other means.

interpretation.semantic_quote: "Article 58(2) of that regulation lists the various corrective powers which the supervisory authority may adopt."
interpretation.systematic_quote: "In accordance with Article 8(3) of the Charter and Article 51(1) and Article 57(1)(a) of the GDPR, the national supervisory authorities are responsible for monitoring compliance with the EU rules concerning the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data."
interpretation.teleological_quote: "The exercise of that responsibility is of particular importance where personal data is transferred to a third country since, as is clear from recital 116 of that regulation, 'when personal data moves across borders outside the Union it may put at increased risk the ability of natural persons to exercise data protection rights in particular to protect themselves from the unlawful use or disclosure of that information'."

reasoning.rule_based_quote: "The supervisory authority is required, under Article 58(2)(f) and (j) of that regulation, to suspend or prohibit a transfer of personal data to a third country if, in its view, in the light of all the circumstances of that transfer, the standard data protection clauses are not or cannot be complied with in that third country."
reasoning.case_law_quote: "As the Court has already held, the protection of personal data resulting from the explicit obligation laid down in Article 8(1) of the Charter is especially important."
reasoning.principle_based_quote: "The supervisory authorities' primary responsibility is to monitor the application of the GDPR and to ensure its enforcement."

holdings.direction_justification: Strengthens supervisory authority powers and creates obligation to act when transfer safeguards are inadequate.

holdings.core_holding: The SCC Decision remains valid as it contains effective mechanisms to ensure compliance with EU protection standards through controller obligations and supervisory authority powers.

interpretation.semantic_quote: "Article 46(1) of the GDPR provides that, in the absence of an adequacy decision, a controller or processor may transfer personal data to a third country only if the controller or processor has provided appropriate safeguards."
interpretation.systematic_quote: "A standard clauses decision differs from an adequacy decision adopted pursuant to Article 45(3) of the GDPR, which seeks, following an examination of the legislation of the third country concerned taking into account, inter alia, the relevant legislation on national security and public authorities' access to personal data, to find with binding effect that a third country ensures an adequate level of protection."
interpretation.teleological_quote: "Article 44, Article 46(1) and Article 46(2)(c) of the GDPR, interpreted in the light of Articles 7, 8 and 47 of the Charter, require that the level of protection of natural persons guaranteed by that regulation is not undermined."

reasoning.rule_based_quote: "It is for that controller or processor to verify, on a case-by-case basis and, where appropriate, in collaboration with the recipient of the data, whether the law of the third country of destination ensures adequate protection, under EU law, of personal data transferred pursuant to standard data protection clauses."
reasoning.case_law_quote: "As the Court held in Schrems, decisions adopted pursuant to Article 46(2)(c) do not bar supervisory authorities from exercising their powers."
reasoning.principle_based_quote: "The contractual mechanism provided for in Article 46(2)(c) of the GDPR is based on the responsibility of the controller or his or her subcontractor established in the European Union."

holdings.direction_justification: Upholds validity of SCCs but imposes significant assessment obligations on controllers before transferring data.

balancing.rights_balance_summary: SCCs valid but must be supplemented where third country law interferes with fundamental rights protection.

holdings.core_holding: The Privacy Shield Decision is invalid because US surveillance programmes and ombudsperson mechanism do not ensure essentially equivalent protection to EU fundamental rights standards.

interpretation.semantic_quote: "Article 1(1) of the Privacy Shield Decision provides that, for the purposes of Article 45(1) of the GDPR, 'the United States ensures an adequate level of protection for personal data transferred from the [European] Union to organisations in the United States under the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield'."
interpretation.systematic_quote: "That decision lays down, as did Decision 2000/520, that those requirements have primacy over those principles, primacy pursuant to which self-certified United States organisations receiving personal data from the European Union are bound to disregard the principles without limitation where they conflict with the requirements."
interpretation.teleological_quote: "In order for the Commission to adopt an adequacy decision pursuant to Article 45(3) of the GDPR, it must find, duly stating reasons, that the third country concerned in fact ensures, by reason of its domestic law or its international commitments, a level of protection of fundamental rights essentially equivalent to that guaranteed in the EU legal order."

reasoning.rule_based_quote: "Section 702 of the FISA does not indicate any limitations on the power it confers to implement surveillance programmes for the purposes of foreign intelligence or the existence of guarantees for non-US persons potentially targeted by those programmes."
reasoning.case_law_quote: "According to settled case-law, the very existence of effective judicial review designed to ensure compliance with provisions of EU law is inherent in the existence of the rule of law."
reasoning.principle_based_quote: "Legislation not providing for any possibility for an individual to pursue legal remedies in order to have access to personal data relating to him or her, or to obtain the rectification or erasure of such data, does not respect the essence of the fundamental right to effective judicial protection, as enshrined in Article 47 of the Charter."
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of Privacy Shield suggested adequate protection but Court shifted to fundamental rights principles under Articles 7, 8 and 47 of Charter to conclude US law fails essential equivalence test.

holdings.direction_justification: Invalidates Privacy Shield due to inadequate protection against US surveillance and lack of effective judicial remedies for EU data subjects.

balancing.necessity_summary: US surveillance laws including Section 702 FISA and E.O. 12333 lack clear and precise rules limiting interference to what is strictly necessary, failing proportionality requirements.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection and effective judicial remedy rights under Charter prevail over US national security interests justifying mass surveillance.

holdings.core_holding: Judicial independence precludes indefinite extension of terms of office of members of a judicial disciplinary body without express legal basis and time limits.

interpretation.systematic_quote: In accordance with the principle of the separation of powers which characterises the operation of the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary must in particular be ensured in relation to the legislature and the executive.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The very existence of effective judicial review designed to ensure compliance with EU law is of the essence of the rule of law.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It should be recalled that every Member State must, in accordance with the second subparagraph of Article 19(1) TEU, ensure that the bodies which are called upon, as 'courts or tribunals' within the meaning of EU law, to rule on questions relating to the application or interpretation of EU law and which thus come within its judicial system in the fields covered by EU law, meet the requirements of effective judicial protection, including that of independence.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Since the prospect of opening a disciplinary investigation is, as such, liable to exert pressure on those who have the task of adjudicating in a dispute, it is essential that a body competent to conduct investigations and bring disciplinary proceedings should act objectively and impartially in the performance of its duties and, to that end, be free from any external influence.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: It is settled case-law of the Court that the guarantees of independence and impartiality required under EU law presuppose rules that are such as to dispel any reasonable doubt, in the minds of individuals, as to the imperviousness of the body in question to external factors and its neutrality with respect to the interests before it.

holdings.direction_justification: This holding concerns judicial independence requirements rather than data protection rights of individuals versus controller interests.

holdings.core_holding: Disclosure of banking data concerning judges and family members for integrity verification falls within the material scope of the GDPR.

interpretation.semantic_quote: That disclosure constitutes the making available of those personal data to that body.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Neither the fact that the information which is the subject of the national provisions relates to judges nor the fact that that information might have certain links with the performance of their duties is, in itself, such as to remove those national provisions from the scope of the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That provision, read in the light of recital 16 of the GDPR, has the sole purpose of excluding from the scope of that regulation the processing of personal data carried out by State authorities in the course of an activity which is intended to safeguard national security or of an activity which can be classified in the same category.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 2(1) of the GDPR gives a very broad definition of its material scope.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Furthermore, the Court has previously held that neither the fact that the information which is the subject of the national provisions relates to judges nor the fact that that information might have certain links with the performance of their duties is, in itself, such as to remove those national provisions from the scope of the GDPR.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope ensures data protection applies to judges' and family members' banking data.

holdings.core_holding: A court authorizing disclosure of personal data to another judicial body is not a controller when it only verifies legal conditions without determining processing purposes.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under Article 4(7) of the GDPR, the concept of 'controller' covers natural or legal persons, public authorities, agencies or other bodies which, alone or jointly with others, determine the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The protection of the data subjects would be undermined if point 7 of Article 4 of the GDPR were interpreted restrictively to cover only those cases in which the purposes and means of the data processing performed by a person, a public authority, an agency or a body are expressly determined by national law, even where those purposes and means are apparent, in essence, from the legal provisions governing the activity of the entity concerned.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That provision seeks to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', in accordance with the objective pursued by the GDPR, effective and complete protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and, in particular, a high level of protection of the right of every person to the protection of personal data concerning him or her.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: In order to establish whether a person or entity is to be classified as a controller within the meaning of Article 4(7) of the GDPR, it must therefore be examined whether that person or entity determines, alone or jointly with others, the purposes and means of the processing or whether those purposes and means are determined by national law.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Having regard to the broad definition of the concept of 'controller' within the meaning of Article 4(7) of the GDPR, the determination of the purposes and means of the processing and, where appropriate, the nomination of that controller by national law may not only be explicit but also implicit.

holdings.direction_justification: Neither expands nor restricts data subject rights; clarifies that the authorizing court lacks sufficient control over processing to be a controller.

holdings.core_holding: A court authorizing data disclosure is not a supervisory authority unless entrusted by the Member State with monitoring GDPR application.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 51(1) of the GDPR requires Member States to provide for one or more independent public authorities which are to be responsible for monitoring the application of that regulation.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Those authorities have the primary task, under Article 51(1) and (2) and Article 57(1)(a) and (g) of the GDPR, to monitor and enforce the application of that regulation, while contributing to its consistent application within the European Union, in order to protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons in relation to the processing of their personal data and to facilitate the free flow of such data within the European Union.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The establishment of such authorities, which is also provided for by primary EU law, namely Article 8(3) of the Charter and Article 16(2) TFEU, is an essential component of the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Member States are required, in accordance with Article 51(4) of the GDPR, to notify to the Commission the provisions of their law and any subsequent amendments that they adopt pursuant to Chapter VI of that regulation, in particular those concerning the supervisory authority or authorities which they have entrusted with the task of monitoring the application of that regulation.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The establishment of such authorities, which is also provided for by primary EU law, namely Article 8(3) of the Charter and Article 16(2) TFEU, is an essential component of the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data.

holdings.direction_justification: Clarifies institutional roles without expanding or restricting data subject rights directly.
