reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has clarified that the purpose of Article 9(1) of that regulation is to ensure enhanced protection as regards processing which, because of the particular sensitivity of the data processed, is liable to constitute a particularly serious interference with the fundamental rights to respect for private life and to the protection of personal data, guaranteed by Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Those considerations apply even where the data concerned fall within the special categories referred to in Article 9 of that regulation, such as data concerning health.

holdings.direction_justification: Allows medical service to process health data of its own employees, recognizing dual function and rejecting requirement for neutral third party.

balancing.balance_summary: The Court rejected the requirement that only a neutral third party could process employee health data, allowing controller's dual function as employer and medical service.

holdings.core_holding: Article 9(3) does not require controllers to prevent all colleagues from accessing employee health data, though Member State law or security principles may impose such obligations.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Personal data referred to in paragraph 1 may be processed for the purposes referred to in point (h) of paragraph 2 when those data are processed by or under the responsibility of a professional subject to the obligation of professional secrecy under Union or Member State law.
interpretation.systematic_quote: By adopting Article 9(3) of that regulation, which refers specifically to Article 9(2)(h) of that article, the EU legislature defined the specific protection measures it intended to impose on controllers of such processing, which consist in such processing being reserved to persons subject to an obligation of secrecy.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows, as the Advocate General points out in essence in point 43 of his Opinion, that Article 9(3) of the GDPR cannot serve as a legal basis for a measure guaranteeing that no colleague of the data subject may have access to data relating to the data subject's state of health.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It has already been held that, in so far as Articles 7 to 11 of the GDPR, which appear, like Articles 5 and 6 thereof, in Chapter II of that regulation, are intended to clarify the scope of the data controller's obligations under Article 5(1)(a) and Article 6(1) of that regulation.

holdings.direction_justification: Does not require absolute colleague exclusion under Article 9(3), but recognizes Member States may impose such requirements and security principles apply.

holdings.core_holding: Processing health data under Article 9(2)(h) must also satisfy at least one lawfulness condition under Article 6(1) in addition to Article 9 requirements.

interpretation.semantic_quote: In addition, it should be noted that recital 51 of the GDPR expressly states that, 'in addition to the specific requirements' for the processing of 'particularly sensitive' data, which are set out in Article 9(2) and (3) of that regulation, 'the general principles and other rules of [that] Regulation should [also] apply [to such processing], in particular as regards the conditions for lawful processing'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It should be recalled that Articles 5, 6 and 9 of the GDPR are in Chapter II of that regulation, entitled 'Principles', and concern principles relating to processing of personal data, conditions for the lawfulness of processing and processing of special categories of personal data, respectively.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Therefore, in accordance with the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, processing of 'particularly sensitive' data, such as data concerning health, is lawful only if at least one of the conditions set out in points (a) to (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) is satisfied.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Therefore, the Court has repeatedly held that any processing of personal data must comply with the principles relating to the processing of data which are set out in Article 5(1) of the GDPR and satisfy the conditions governing lawfulness of the processing which are listed in Article 6 of that regulation.

holdings.direction_justification: Requires cumulative compliance with both Article 9 and Article 6(1), increasing controller obligations for health data processing.

holdings.core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82(1) fulfils a compensatory function only, not a dissuasive or punitive function.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 82(1) of the GDPR states that 'any person who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of this Regulation shall have the right to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In that regard, first, it is apparent from the wording of Articles 24 and 32 of the GDPR that those provisions merely require the controller to adopt technical and organisational measures intended to avoid, in so far as it is at all possible, any personal data breach.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Financial compensation based on that article must be regarded as 'full and effective' if it allows the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in its entirety, without there being any need, for the purposes of such compensation for the damage in its entirety, to require the payment of punitive damages.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has interpreted that provision as meaning that a mere infringement of the GDPR is not sufficient to confer a right to compensation, after pointing out, inter alia, that the existence of 'damage' which has been 'suffered' constitutes one of the conditions for the right to compensation laid down in Article 82(1).

holdings.direction_justification: Rejects punitive damages function, limiting compensation to actual damage suffered and excluding consideration of infringement gravity.

holdings.core_holding: Controller liability under Article 82 requires fault, which is presumed but rebuttable; fault severity does not affect damages amount.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 82(3) of the GDPR specifies, from that perspective, that a controller is exempt from liability under Article 82(2) of that regulation if it proves that it is not in any way responsible for the event giving rise to the damage.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It therefore follows from a combined analysis of those various provisions of Article 82 of the GDPR that that article provides for fault-based liability in which the burden of proof rests not on the person who has suffered damage, but on the controller.
interpretation.teleological_quote: With regard to the objectives of the GDPR, it is clear from recitals 4 to 8 of that regulation that it seeks to strike a balance between the interests of controllers of personal data and the rights of data subjects whose personal data are processed.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 82(2) of the GDPR provides that any controller involved in processing is to be liable for the damage caused by processing which infringes that regulation.
reasoning.case_law_quote: First, as the Advocate General observes, in essence, in point 93 of his Opinion, it would not be consistent with the objective of such a high level of protection to opt for an interpretation according to which data subjects who have suffered damage as a result of an infringement of the GDPR should, in an action for damages under Article 82 of that regulation, bear the burden of proving not only the existence of that infringement and the damage resulting therefrom for them, but also the existence of a fault on the part of the controller.

holdings.direction_justification: Presumed fault benefits data subjects by reversing burden of proof, but excluding fault severity from damages calculation benefits controllers.

balancing.balance_summary: Balances interests by presuming controller fault while limiting damages to actual harm regardless of fault severity.

holdings.core_holding: Consent for cookie storage is not valid when obtained through a pre-checked checkbox that users must deselect to refuse consent.

interpretation.semantic_quote: The wording 'given his or her consent' does, however, lend itself to a literal interpretation according to which action is required on the part of the user in order to give his or her consent.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 2(f) of that directive, which defines 'consent', for the purposes thereof, refers, in that regard, to the 'data subject's consent' set out in Directive 95/46.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Lastly, as regards the origins of Article 5(3) of Directive 2002/58, the initial wording of that provision provided only for the requirement that the user had the 'right to refuse' the storage of cookies, after having received, pursuant to Directive 95/46, clear and comprehensive information, inter alia, regarding the purpose of the data processing.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 7(a) of Directive 95/46 provides that the data subject's consent may make such processing lawful provided that the data subject has given his or her consent 'unambiguously'.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In addition, according to settled case-law of the Court, the interpretation of a provision of EU law requires that account be taken not only of its wording and the objectives it pursues, but also of its legislative context and the provisions of EU law as a whole.

holdings.direction_justification: Strict interpretation of consent requiring active affirmative action protects users against unwanted cookie tracking via default pre-checked boxes.

holdings.core_holding: The consent requirement for cookie storage applies regardless of whether the stored information constitutes personal data.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 5(3) of Directive 2002/58 refers to 'the storing of information' and 'the gaining of access to information already stored', without characterising that information or specifying that it must be personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: That protection applies to any information stored in such terminal equipment, regardless of whether or not it is personal data, and is intended, in particular, as is clear from that recital, to protect users from the risk that hidden identifiers and other similar devices enter those users' terminal equipment without their knowledge.
interpretation.teleological_quote: As the Advocate General stated in point 107 of his Opinion, that provision aims to protect the user from interference with his or her private sphere, regardless of whether or not that interference involves personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 5(3) of Directive 2002/58 refers to 'the storing of information' and 'the gaining of access to information already stored', without characterising that information or specifying that it must be personal data.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: That interpretation is borne out by recital 24 of Directive 2002/58, according to which any information stored in the terminal equipment of users of electronic communications networks are part of the private sphere of the users requiring protection under the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.

holdings.direction_justification: Extends protection to all information stored on user terminal equipment, not just personal data, broadening scope of user privacy protection.

holdings.core_holding: Service providers must inform users about cookie duration and whether third parties may access the cookies.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Clear and comprehensive information implies that a user is in a position to be able to determine easily the consequences of any consent he or she might give and ensure that the consent given is well informed.
interpretation.systematic_quote: That information includes, inter alia, under Article 10 of Directive 95/46, in addition to the identity of the controller and the purposes of the processing for which the data are intended, any further information such as the recipients or categories of recipients of the data in so far as such further information is necessary, having regard to the specific circumstances in which the data are processed, to guarantee fair processing in respect of the data subject.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Information on the duration of the operation of cookies must be regarded as meeting the requirement of fair data processing provided for in that article in that, in a situation such as that at issue in the main proceedings, a long, or even unlimited, duration means collecting a large amount of information on users' surfing behaviour and how often they may visit the websites of the organiser of the promotional lottery's advertising partners.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 10 of Directive 95/46, to which Article 5(3) of Directive 2002/58 and Article 13 of Regulation 2016/679 refer, lists the information with which the controller must provide a data subject from whom data relating to himself are collected.

holdings.direction_justification: Expands transparency obligations by requiring disclosure of cookie duration and third-party access, enhancing user information rights.

holdings.core_holding: An entity commissioning a mobile app may be a controller if it participated in determining processing purposes and means, even without performing processing operations itself.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 4(7) of the GDPR defines the concept of 'controller' broadly as the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or any other body which, alone or jointly with others, 'determines the purposes and means of the processing' of personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is apparent from that provision, read in the light of recital 74 of the GDPR, that an entity, provided that it satisfies the condition laid down by Article 4(7) of that regulation, is responsible and liable not only for any processing of personal data which it itself carries out, but also for any such processing carried out on its behalf.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The objective of that broad definition consists, in accordance with the objective pursued by the GDPR, in ensuring effective protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and, in particular, in ensuring a high level of protection of the right of every person to the protection of personal data concerning him or her.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: In order to establish whether an entity such as the NVSC may be regarded as a controller within the meaning of Article 4(7) of the GDPR, it is necessary to examine whether that entity actually exerted influence, for its own purposes, over the determination of the purposes and means of the processing in question.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held that any natural or legal person who exerts influence over the processing of such data, for his, her or its own purposes, and who participates, as a result, in the determination of the purposes and means of that processing, may be regarded as a controller in respect of such processing.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of controller captures entities that commission apps but do not themselves process data, expanding accountability.

holdings.core_holding: Joint controller classification does not require a formal arrangement between entities regarding purposes, means, or terms of joint control.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under Article 26(1) of the GDPR, 'joint controllers' exist where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing.
interpretation.systematic_quote: However, the existence of such an arrangement constitutes not a precondition for two or more entities to be classified as joint controllers, but rather an obligation which Article 26(1) of the GDPR imposes on joint controllers, once they have been classified as such, for the purposes of compliance with their obligations under that regulation.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Thus, such classification arises solely from the fact that several entities have participated in the determination of the purposes and means of processing.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has held, in order to be regarded as a joint controller, a natural or legal person therefore must independently meet the definition of 'controller' laid down in Article 4(7) of the GDPR.

holdings.direction_justification: Broadens joint controller status by not requiring formal arrangements, making it easier to hold multiple parties accountable.

holdings.core_holding: Using personal data for IT testing constitutes processing unless the data are anonymous, anonymized, or fictitious relating to non-existent persons.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It is therefore apparent from the wording of that provision, and in particular from the expression 'any operation', that the EU legislature intended to confer a broad scope upon the concept of 'processing'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It follows from recital 26 of the GDPR and from the very definition of the concept of 'personal data' provided in Article 4(1) of that regulation that neither 'anonymous information, namely information which does not relate to an identified or identifiable natural person', nor 'personal data rendered anonymous in such a manner that the data subject is not or no longer identifiable', is covered by that concept.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Consequently, the question whether personal data are used for the purposes of IT testing or for another purpose has no bearing on whether the operation in question is classified as 'processing' within the meaning of that provision.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It is therefore apparent from the wording of that provision, and in particular from the expression 'any operation', that the EU legislature intended to confer a broad scope upon the concept of 'processing'.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of processing covers IT testing purposes, expanding GDPR applicability to development activities.

holdings.core_holding: Administrative fines require intentional or negligent infringement; controllers may be fined for processor operations unless processor acted outside the agreed framework.

interpretation.semantic_quote: As regards, in the first place, the question whether an administrative fine may be imposed pursuant to Article 83 of the GDPR only in so far as it is established that the controller or processor has intentionally or negligently committed an infringement referred to in paragraphs 4 to 6 of that article, it is apparent from paragraph 1 thereof that such fines must be effective, proportionate and dissuasive.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It thus follows from such a combined reading of those provisions that the determination of substantive conditions for imposing such administrative fines falls outside the scope of that power.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Through their dissuasive effect, administrative fines contribute to strengthening the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and are therefore a key element in ensuring respect for the rights of those persons, in accordance with the purpose of that regulation, which is to ensure a high level of protection for such persons with regard to the processing of personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It thus follows from the wording of Article 83(2) of the GDPR that only infringements of the provisions of that regulation which are committed wrongfully by the controller, that is to say, those committed intentionally or negligently, may result in an administrative fine being imposed on that controller pursuant to that article.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In that regard, it must also be stated, in relation to the question whether an infringement has been committed intentionally or negligently and is therefore liable to be penalised by way of an administrative fine under Article 83 of the GDPR, that a controller may be penalised for conduct falling within the scope of the GDPR where that controller could not have been unaware of the infringing nature of its conduct, whether or not it was aware that it was infringing the provisions of the GDPR.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: However, the EU legislature did not deem it necessary, for the purpose of ensuring such a high level of protection, to provide for the imposition of administrative fines in the absence of fault.

holdings.direction_justification: Requires fault for fines (pro-controller) but allows controller liability for processor actions within agreed scope (pro-data subject).

holdings.core_holding: Employee error in providing documents containing personal data to an unauthorized third party is not sufficient in itself to conclude that the controller's technical and organizational measures were inappropriate.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It is apparent, accordingly, from the wording of Articles 24 and 32 of the GDPR that the appropriateness of the measures implemented by the controller must be assessed in a concrete manner, taking into account the various criteria referred to in those articles and the data protection needs specifically inherent in the processing concerned and the risks arising from the latter.
interpretation.systematic_quote: That literal interpretation is supported by reading Articles 24 and 32 together with Article 5(2) and Article 82 of that regulation, read in the light of recitals 74, 76 and 83 thereof, from which it follows, in particular, that the controller is obliged to mitigate the risks of personal data breaches and not prevent all breaches of those data.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Such an allocation of the burden of proof is capable not only of encouraging the controllers of those data of adopting the security measures required by the GDPR, but also in retaining the effectiveness of the right to compensation provided for in Article 82 of that regulation and upholding the intentions of the EU legislature referred to in recital 11 thereof.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 24 of the GDPR lays down a general obligation, on the part of the controller of personal data, to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure that that processing is performed in accordance with that regulation and to be able to demonstrate this.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Therefore, the Court interpreted Articles 24 and 32 of the GDPR as meaning that unauthorised disclosure of personal data or unauthorised access to those data by a 'third party', within the meaning of Article 4, point 10, of that regulation, are not sufficient, in themselves, for it to be held that the technical and organisational measures implemented by the controller in question were not 'appropriate', within the meaning of Articles 24 and 32.

holdings.direction_justification: Holding prevents automatic finding of inadequate security measures based solely on occurrence of a breach, requiring concrete assessment that benefits controllers.

holdings.core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82 fulfills a compensatory function requiring full compensation for damage suffered, not a punitive function.

interpretation.systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The right of any person to seek compensation for damage reinforces the operational nature of the protection rules laid down by that regulation and is likely to discourage the reoccurrence of unlawful conduct.

reasoning.case_law_quote: In that regard, the Court held that Article 82 of the GDPR fulfils a function that is compensatory and not punitive, contrary to other provisions of that regulation also contained in Chapter VIII thereof, namely Articles 83 and 84, which have, for their part, essentially a punitive purpose, since they permit the imposition of administrative fines and other penalties, respectively.

holdings.direction_justification: Clarifies the nature of compensation without expanding or limiting rights in a way that favors either party.

holdings.core_holding: Article 82 does not require that the severity of the controller's infringement be taken into consideration when determining compensation amounts.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It follows from Article 82 of the GDPR that, first, establishing the liability of the controller is, in particular, subject to fault on the part of the controller, which is presupposed unless it proves that it is not in any way responsible for the event giving rise to the damage, and secondly, Article 82 does not require that the severity of that fault is taken into consideration when setting the amount of the compensation allocated for non-material damage under that provision.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Having regard to the compensatory function of the right to compensation laid down in Article 82 of the GDPR, that provision does not require taking into consideration the severity of the infringement of that regulation, that the controller is presumed to have made, while setting the amount of the compensation allocated for non-material damage under that provision, but requires that that amount is set in a way that the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation is compensated in full.

reasoning.case_law_quote: In addition, the Court stated that, having regard to the compensatory function of the right to compensation laid down in Article 82 of the GDPR, that provision does not require taking into consideration the severity of the infringement of that regulation.

holdings.direction_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage without allowing increases based on severity of infringement, benefiting controllers facing minor but technically serious violations.

holdings.core_holding: A person seeking compensation must establish both an infringement of the GDPR and that the infringement caused material or non-material damage.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It is apparent from the wording of that provision that the mere infringement of the GDPR is not sufficient to confer a right to compensation.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The Court stated that a person concerned by an infringement of the GDPR which had negative consequences for him or her is, however, required to demonstrate that those consequences constitute non-material damage, within the meaning of Article 82 of that regulation, since the mere infringement of the provisions thereof are not sufficient to confer a right to compensation.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: The existence of 'damage' or 'harm' which has been 'suffered' constitutes one of the conditions for the right to compensation laid down in Article 82(1), as does the existence of an infringement of that regulation and of a causal link between that damage and that infringement, those three conditions being cumulative.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court also held that Article 82(1) of the GDPR precludes a national rule or practice which makes compensation for non-material damage, within the meaning of that provision, subject to the condition that the damage suffered by the data subject, as defined in Article 4, point 1, of that regulation, has reached a certain degree of seriousness.

holdings.direction_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, creating an additional burden that benefits controllers.

holdings.core_holding: When an unauthorized third party did not become aware of personal data, mere fear of future misuse does not constitute non-material damage sufficient for compensation.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Having regard to the absence of any reference in Article 82(1) of the GDPR to the domestic law of the Member States, the concept of 'non-material damage', within the meaning of that provision, must be given an autonomous and uniform definition specific to EU law.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The Court held that it is apparent not only from the wording of Article 82(1) of the GDPR, read in the light of recitals 85 and 146 of that regulation, which encourage the acceptance of a broad interpretation of the concept of 'non-material damage' within the meaning of that first provision, but also the objective of ensuring a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data, which is referred to by the regulation, that the fear experienced by a data subject with regard to a possible misuse of his or her personal data by third parties as a result of an infringement of that regulation is capable, in itself, of constituting 'non-material damage'.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: However, the fact remains that it is for the applicant in an action for compensation under Article 82 of the GDPR to demonstrate the existence of such damage.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Similarly, on the basis of considerations of a literal, systemic and teleological nature, the Court held that the loss of control of the personal data for a short period of time may cause the data subject 'non-material damage', within the meaning of Article 82(1) of the GDPR, giving rise to a right to compensation, subject to that person demonstrating having actually suffered such damage, however minimal.

holdings.direction_justification: Excludes compensation for hypothetical fear when unauthorized party did not actually access the data, limiting recoverable non-material damage.

holdings.core_holding: Data identifying a natural person representing a legal person (name, surname, signature, contact details) constitutes personal data, and its disclosure is processing regardless of purpose.

interpretation.semantic_quote: According to settled case-law, the use of the expression 'any information' in the definition of the concept of 'personal data' in that provision reflects the aim of the EU legislature to assign a wide scope to that concept, which potentially encompasses all kinds of information, not only objective but also subjective, in the form of opinions and assessments, provided that it 'relates' to the data subject.
interpretation.systematic_quote: As the Commission observed, that interpretation cannot be invalidated by recital 14 of the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That interpretation is consistent with the objective pursued by the GDPR, as is set out in Article 1 thereof and in recitals 1 and 10 thereof, consisting, inter alia, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data, as enshrined in Article 8(1) of the Charter and Article 16(1) TFEU.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Under point 1 of Article 4 of the GDPR, 'personal data' means 'any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person'.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Thus, information relating to the identity of identified or identifiable natural persons who, as a body constituted pursuant to law, or as members of such a body, are authorised to represent a company in dealings with third parties constitutes 'personal data' within the meaning of point 1 of Article 4 of the GDPR.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope includes representatives of legal persons, expanding GDPR protection.

holdings.core_holding: National case-law requiring prior consultation of data subjects before disclosure of official documents is permissible provided it does not impose disproportionate restrictions on public access.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR provides that the basis for the processing referred to in Article 6(1)(c) and (e) is to be defined, as the case may be, by EU or Member State law to which the controller is subject.
interpretation.systematic_quote: That article must be read in the light, first, of recital 4 of the GDPR, which states, inter alia, that the right to the protection of personal data is not an absolute right, second, of recital 154 of that regulation, from which it is apparent, inter alia, that public access to official documents may be considered to be in the public interest.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Such an obligation is such as to ensure lawful, fair and transparent processing in respect of that data subject, within the meaning of Article 5(1)(a) of the GDPR, by allowing him or her to express his or her views on the proposed disclosure.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 6(1)(c) of the GDPR provides that processing may be lawful if and to the extent that it is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Although, as is apparent from recital 10 of the GDPR, Member States have the power to maintain or introduce national provisions to further specify the application of the rules of that regulation, they must nevertheless use their discretion under the conditions and within the limits provided for by that regulation and must therefore legislate in such a way as not to undermine the content and objectives thereof.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: Furthermore, in accordance with the principle of proportionality, Member States must ensure that the practical consequences, in particular of an organisational nature, arising from the additional requirements which they have laid down are not excessive.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of Article 6 permits Member State rules, but Court invokes proportionality principle to conclude that such rules cannot impose disproportionate restrictions on public access.

holdings.direction_justification: Permits national data subject protections but limits them through proportionality to protect public access rights.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court applied proportionality to conclude that prior consultation obligations must not require disproportionate effort or result in disproportionate restriction on public access.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Neither right prevails absolutely; the Court requires reconciliation between data protection and public access, with proportionality as the balancing mechanism.

holdings.core_holding: Oral disclosure of information on criminal proceedings concerning a natural person constitutes processing of personal data falling within the GDPR's material scope when the data form part of a filing system.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 4(2) of the GDPR defines the concept of 'processing' as 'any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 2 of that regulation, which determines that scope, provides, in paragraph 1, that that regulation applies to the processing 'wholly or partly by automated means' and to the processing 'other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That interpretation of the concept of 'processing' is supported by the objective pursued by the GDPR, which seeks, inter alia, as is apparent from Article 1 thereof and recitals 1 and 10 thereof, to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data, as enshrined in Article 8(1) of the Charter and Article 16(1) TFEU.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It is apparent in particular from the expression 'any operation' that the EU legislature intended to give the concept of 'processing' a broad scope, which is corroborated by the non-exhaustive nature, expressed by the phrase 'such as', of the operations listed in that provision.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held that, in accordance with the objective set out in paragraph 34 of the present judgment, that provision broadly defines the concept of 'filing system', in particular by referring to 'any' structured set of personal data.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of processing to include oral disclosure expands GDPR scope and prevents circumvention of data protection rules.

holdings.core_holding: Criminal conviction data in court filing systems cannot be disclosed orally to any person for public access purposes without the requester establishing a specific interest in obtaining the data.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Under that provision, processing of those data 'shall be carried out only under the control of official authority', unless it is 'authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is important to note that, in accordance with the settled case-law of the Court, any processing of personal data must, first, comply with the principles relating to the processing of data established in Article 5 of the GDPR and, secondly, in the light, in particular, of the principle of the lawfulness of processing, laid down in Article 5(1)(a), satisfy one of the conditions of the lawfulness of the processing listed in Article 6 of that regulation.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In the light in particular of the sensitivity of data relating to criminal convictions and of the seriousness of the interference with the fundamental rights of data subjects to respect for private life and to the protection of personal data, which is caused by the disclosure of such data, it must be held that those rights prevail over the public's interest in having access to official documents.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Thus, a national court is required to apply the requirements of the GDPR as a whole, even if there is no specific provision in the applicable national law allowing regard to be had to the interests of the persons whose personal data are at issue.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held that the processing of data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures is, because of the particular sensitivity of those data, liable to constitute a particularly serious interference with the fundamental rights to respect for private life and to the protection of personal data, guaranteed by Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The fundamental rights to respect for private life and to the protection of personal data are not absolute rights, as stated in recital 4 of the GDPR, but must be considered in relation to their function in society and be weighed against other fundamental rights.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of Article 86 permits disclosure for public access purposes, but Court shifted to fundamental rights balancing principle to conclude that data subject rights prevail over public access interest for criminal conviction data.

holdings.direction_justification: Court requires specific interest to be established before disclosure, prioritizing data subject privacy over unrestricted public access to criminal records.

balancing.necessity_summary: Court examined whether disclosure is necessary for public interest task under Article 6(1)(e) and whether legislation provides appropriate safeguards under Article 10, applying strict proportionality given sensitivity of criminal data.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection rights prevail over public access to official documents when criminal conviction data is concerned, requiring requesters to establish specific interest.

holdings.core_holding: An infringement of GDPR provisions conferring rights on data subjects is not sufficient in itself to constitute non-material damage requiring compensation.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 82(1) of the GDPR provides that any person 'who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of this Regulation shall have the right to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: However, that provision merely confers a right to bring an action on a person who considers himself or herself to be a victim of a breach of the rights conferred on him or her by the GDPR, without exempting that person from his or her obligation under Article 82(1) of that regulation to prove that he or she has actually suffered material or non-material damage.
interpretation.teleological_quote: In that regard, it should be noted that recital 85 of the GDPR expressly mentions 'loss of control' among the damage that may be caused by a personal data breach.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: The Court has already interpreted Article 82(1) of the GDPR as meaning that the mere infringement of that regulation is not sufficient to confer a right to compensation, since the existence of 'damage', material or non-material, or of 'damage' which has been 'suffered' constitutes one of the conditions for the right to compensation laid down in Article 82(1).
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held that the loss of control over such data, even for a short period of time, may constitute 'non-material damage', within the meaning of Article 82(1) of that regulation, giving rise to a right to compensation, provided that the data subject can show that he or she has actually suffered such damage, however slight.

holdings.direction_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, raising the threshold for compensation claims.

holdings.core_holding: A controller cannot be exempted from liability merely by claiming that damage was caused by an employee's failure to follow instructions.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 32(4) of the GDPR, relating to the security of processing of personal data, provides that the controller is to take steps to ensure that any natural person acting under the authority of the controller, who has access to such data, does not process them, except on instructions from the controller.
interpretation.systematic_quote: An employee of the controller is indeed a natural person acting under the authority of that controller.
interpretation.teleological_quote: If it were accepted that the controller may be exempted from liability merely by relying on the failure of a person acting under his or her authority, that would undermine the effectiveness of the right to compensation enshrined in Article 82(1) of the GDPR and would not be consistent with the objective of that regulation, which is to ensure a high level of protection for individuals with regard to the processing of their personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It is apparent from Article 82(2) and (3) that that article provides for a fault-based regime, in which the controller is presumed to have participated in the processing constituting the breach of the GDPR in question, so that the burden of proof lies not with the person who has suffered damage but with the controller.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held that it is apparent from a combined analysis of Article 82(2) and (3) that that article provides for a fault-based regime, in which the controller is presumed to have participated in the processing constituting the breach of the GDPR in question.

holdings.direction_justification: Controllers remain liable for employee failures and cannot easily escape responsibility, strengthening data subject compensation rights.

holdings.core_holding: Administrative fine criteria under Article 83 do not apply to compensation assessment, and multiple infringements do not increase damages beyond actual harm suffered.

interpretation.semantic_quote: While Article 83 of that regulation determines the 'general conditions for imposing administrative fines', Article 82 of that regulation governs the 'right to compensation and liability'.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Referring to the sixth sentence of recital 146 of the GDPR, according to which that instrument is intended to ensure 'full and effective compensation for the damage … suffered', the Court noted that, in view of the compensatory function of the right to compensation provided for in Article 82 of that regulation, monetary compensation based on that article must be regarded as 'full and effective' if it allows the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in its entirety.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows that the criteria set out in Article 83 of the GDPR for the purposes of determining the amount of administrative fines, which are also mentioned in recital 148 of that regulation, cannot be used to assess the amount of damages under Article 82 thereof.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court emphasised that Article 82 of the GDPR has a function that is compensatory and not punitive, contrary to other provisions of that regulation also contained in Chapter VIII thereof, namely Articles 83 and 84, which have, for their part, essentially a punitive purpose.

holdings.direction_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage suffered without punitive elements, preventing inflation of damages through multiple infringement counts.

holdings.core_holding: Consumer protection associations may bring representative actions under Article 80(2) GDPR for violations of controller information obligations under Articles 12(1) and 13(1)(c) and (e).

interpretation.semantic_quote: Specifically, as is apparent from the wording of Article 80(2) of the GDPR, the bringing of a representative action on the basis of that provision implies that the infringement of the rights which the data subject derives from that regulation occurs in the course of the processing of personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: That interpretation is supported by a comparison of the different language versions of Article 80(2) of the GDPR and by recital 142 thereof, which states that entities meeting the conditions referred to in Article 80(1) of that regulation must have reasons to consider that the rights of a data subject under that regulation have been infringed as a result of 'the processing of personal data which infringes [that] Regulation'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That interpretation is confirmed, first, by the objective of the GDPR, recalled in paragraph 48 above, of ensuring effective protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and, in particular, a high level of protection of the right of every person to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data concerning him or her.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It therefore follows from Article 5 of the GDPR that the processing of personal data must, inter alia, satisfy specific requirements of transparency with regard to the data subject concerned by such processing.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, a consumer protection association, such as the Federal Union, may fall within the scope of that concept in that it pursues a public interest objective consisting in safeguarding the rights and freedoms of data subjects in their capacity as consumers, since the attainment of such an objective is likely to be related to the protection of the personal data of those persons.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: It follows from the foregoing, in the first place, that the controller's obligation to provide information to subjects of the processing of personal data is the corollary of the right to information which is conferred on those data subjects by Articles 12 and 13 of the GDPR and which thus forms part of the rights which the representative action provided for in Article 80(2) of that regulation seeks to protect.

holdings.direction_justification: Broad interpretation of standing requirements allows consumer associations to bring actions for transparency violations, enhancing enforcement of data subject rights.

holdings.core_holding: When a personal data breach is established, the supervisory authority is not required to exercise corrective powers where such action is not appropriate, necessary, or proportionate.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Thus, under Article 58(2) of the GDPR, the supervisory authority has the power, inter alia, to issue reprimands to a controller or a processor where processing operations have infringed provisions of that regulation.
interpretation.systematic_quote: In order to handle complaints thus lodged, Article 58(1) of the GDPR confers extensive investigative powers on each supervisory authority.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That discretion is, however, limited by the need to ensure a consistent and high level of protection of personal data through strong enforcement of the rules, as is apparent from recitals 7 and 10 of the GDPR.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows that the exercise of a corrective power may, exceptionally and in the light of the particular circumstances of the specific case, not be required, provided that the situation in which the GDPR was infringed has already been made good and that the processing of personal data by the controller thereof in compliance with that regulation is ensured.
reasoning.case_law_quote: Thus, the Court has already held that the supervisory authority must determine which action is appropriate and necessary, and must do so taking into consideration all the circumstances of the specific case and executing its responsibility for ensuring that the GDPR is fully enforced with all due diligence.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: In particular each measure should be appropriate, necessary and proportionate in view of ensuring compliance with this Regulation, taking into account the circumstances of each individual case.

holdings.direction_justification: The ruling confirms that supervisory authorities have discretion not to impose fines or corrective measures even when a breach is established, reducing enforcement pressure on controllers.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court held that corrective measures must be appropriate, necessary, and proportionate to remedy the shortcoming, allowing DPAs to refrain from action when these conditions are not met.

holdings.core_holding: The purpose limitation principle does not preclude copying personal data to a test database for testing and error correction where such processing is compatible with the initial collection purposes.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It is thus apparent from the wording of that provision that it comprises two requirements, one relating to the purposes of the initial collection of the personal data and the other concerning the further processing of those data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It follows from a combined reading of Article 5(1)(b), Article 6(1)(a) and Article 6(4) of Regulation 2016/679 that the question of the compatibility of the further processing of personal data with the purposes for which those data were initially collected arises only if the purposes of that further processing are not identical to the purposes of the initial collection.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Furthermore, in the third place, as the Advocate General emphasised, in essence, in point 27 of his Opinion, those criteria limit the reuse of personal data previously collected by ensuring a balance between, on the one hand, the need for predictability and legal certainty regarding the purposes of the processing of personal data previously collected and, on the other hand, the recognition of a degree of flexibility for the controller in the management of those data, and thereby contribute to the attainment of the objective of ensuring a consistent and high level of protection of natural persons, which is set out in recital 10 of Regulation 2016/679.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: In accordance with settled case-law, the interpretation of a provision of EU law requires account to be taken not only of its wording, but also of its context, and the objectives and purpose pursued by the act of which it forms part.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It should be recalled that it follows from settled case-law of the Court that it is solely for the national court before which the dispute has been brought, and which must assume responsibility for the subsequent judicial decision, to determine, in the light of the particular circumstances of the case, both the need for a preliminary ruling in order to enable it to deliver judgment and the relevance of the questions which it submits to the Court.

holdings.direction_justification: The Court permits controllers flexibility to copy data to test databases for legitimate operational purposes without requiring separate consent or legal basis.

holdings.core_holding: The storage limitation principle precludes retaining personal data in a test database longer than necessary for conducting tests and correcting errors.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It is thus unequivocally clear from the wording of that article that the principle of 'storage limitation' requires the controller to be able to demonstrate, in accordance with the principle of accountability referred to in paragraph 24 of the present judgment, that personal data are kept only for as long as is necessary for the purposes for which they were collected or for which they have been further processed.
interpretation.systematic_quote: First, as is apparent from such Article 6, where the data subject has not given consent to the processing of his or her personal data for one or more specific purposes, in accordance with Article 6(1)(a) of Regulation 2016/679, the processing must, as is apparent from Article 6(1)(b) to (f), satisfy a requirement of necessity.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Such an interpretation is, in the third place, consistent with the objective pursued by Article 5(1)(e) of Regulation 2016/679, which, as was recalled in paragraph 48 of the present judgment, is, inter alia, to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons within the European Union with regard to the processing of personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It is thus unequivocally clear from the wording of that article that the principle of 'storage limitation' requires the controller to be able to demonstrate, in accordance with the principle of accountability referred to in paragraph 24 of the present judgment, that personal data are kept only for as long as is necessary for the purposes for which they were collected or for which they have been further processed.
reasoning.case_law_quote: It follows that even initially lawful processing of data may over time become incompatible with Regulation 2016/679 where those data are no longer necessary for such purposes and that the data must be erased when those purposes have been served.

holdings.direction_justification: The Court strictly enforces storage limitation, rejecting the controller's oversight argument and requiring deletion once the test purpose is fulfilled.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court applied the necessity standard from Article 5(1)(e), finding data must not be kept longer than necessary for the specific purpose, and the controller's oversight excuse was irrelevant.

holdings.core_holding: National law cannot require that a GDPR infringement be attributed to an identified natural person before imposing an administrative fine on a legal person controller.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 4(7) of the GDPR defines the concept of 'controller' broadly, as referring to the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It thus follows from a combined reading of Article 4(7), Article 83 and Article 58(2)(i) of the GDPR that an administrative fine in respect of an infringement referred to in Article 83(4) to (6) may also be imposed on legal persons where they are controllers.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The objective of that broad definition in Article 4(7) of the GDPR – which expressly includes legal persons – is, in a manner consistent with the objective of the GDPR, to ensure effective protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and, in particular, to ensure a high level of protection of the right of every person to the protection of personal data concerning him or her.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It is apparent from Article 83(4) to (6) of the GDPR, which concerns the calculation of administrative fines in respect of the infringements listed in those paragraphs, that, where the addressee of the administrative fine is or forms part of an undertaking, within the meaning of Articles 101 and 102 TFEU, the maximum amount of the administrative fine is calculated on the basis of a percentage of the total worldwide annual turnover in the preceding business year of the undertaking concerned.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has previously held that a natural or legal person who exerts influence over the processing of personal data, for his own purposes, and who participates, as a result, in the determination of the purposes and means of that processing, may be regarded as a controller.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: To allow Member States to make it a requirement, unilaterally and as a necessary condition for the imposition of an administrative fine pursuant to Article 83 of the GDPR on a controller who is a legal person, that the infringement in question is first attributed or attributable to an identified natural person, would be contrary to that purpose of the GDPR.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of Article 4(7) defines controller broadly including legal persons; Court shifts to effectiveness and harmonization purposes to reject Member State requirements that undermine direct liability of legal persons.

holdings.direction_justification: Holding ensures effective enforcement by allowing direct fines on legal person controllers without requiring attribution to a natural person.

holdings.core_holding: An administrative fine under Article 83 GDPR may only be imposed where the controller intentionally or negligently committed the infringement.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Accordingly, it follows from the wording of Article 83(2) of the GDPR that only infringements of the provisions of that regulation committed wrongfully by the controller, that is to say those committed intentionally or negligently, can result in a fine being imposed on the controller pursuant to that article.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 83(2) of the GDPR must be read in conjunction with Article 83(3) thereof, the purpose of which is to lay down the consequences of cumulative infringements of that regulation, according to which 'if a controller or processor intentionally or negligently, for the same or linked processing operations, infringes several provisions of this Regulation, the total amount of the administrative fine shall not exceed the amount specified for the gravest infringement'.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Through their deterrent effect, administrative fines contribute to strengthening the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and therefore constitute a key element in ensuring respect for the rights of those persons, in accordance with the purpose of that regulation of ensuring a high level of protection of such persons with regard to the processing of personal data.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Those factors include, in Article 83(2)(b) thereof, 'the intentional or negligent character of the infringement'.
reasoning.case_law_quote: A controller can be penalised for conduct falling within the scope of the GDPR where that controller could not be unaware of the infringing nature of its conduct, whether or not it is aware that it is infringing the provisions of the GDPR.

holdings.direction_justification: Requires proof of intentional or negligent conduct before imposing administrative fines, rejecting strict liability.

holdings.core_holding: The GDPR applies to PNR data processing by private operators and to API/maritime directive processing, but not to PNR Directive processing carried out by PIUs or competent authorities.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 2(2)(d) of the GDPR draws such a distinction, since it is clearly apparent from the wording of that provision that two conditions need to be met for data processing to fall within the scope of the exception it lays down.
interpretation.systematic_quote: As is apparent from recital 19 of the GDPR, the reason for that exception is that the processing of personal data by authorities competent for the purposes, inter alia, of the prevention and detection of criminal offences is governed by a more specific EU legal act, namely Directive 2016/680.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Directive 2016/680 lays down the specific rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to such processing operations, respecting the specific nature of those activities in the fields of judicial cooperation in criminal matters and police cooperation.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from Article 2(2)(d) of the GDPR that two conditions need to be met for data processing to fall within the scope of the exception it lays down.
reasoning.case_law_quote: As the Court has already held, the protection of personal data resulting from the explicit obligation laid down in Article 8(1) of the Charter is especially important for the right to respect for private life.

holdings.direction_justification: The holding clarifies the boundary between GDPR and Directive 2016/680 without expanding or restricting rights.

holdings.core_holding: The PNR Directive is valid when interpreted in light of Charter Articles 7, 8, 21 and 52(1), subject to strict interpretive safeguards limiting data scope, processing purposes, and automated assessment.

interpretation.semantic_quote: PNR data collected and provided in accordance with Annex I to the PNR Directive must relate directly to the flight operated and the passenger concerned and must be limited in such a way as to meet solely the legitimate requirements of public authorities.
interpretation.systematic_quote: That directive, in Article 1(2) thereof read in conjunction with Article 3(8) and (9) thereof as well as Annex II thereto, circumscribes the purposes for which those data are to be processed.
interpretation.teleological_quote: The objectives of the directive are to ensure the internal security of the European Union and thus protect the life and safety of persons, while creating a legal framework that guarantees a high level of protection of passengers' fundamental rights.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: It follows from Article 6(4) of the PNR Directive that any assessment of passengers by those means must be carried out in a non-discriminatory manner.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held that the automated processing of PNR data, since it is carried out on the basis of unverified personal data and are based on pre-determined models and criteria, necessarily presents some margin of error.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The protection of the fundamental right to respect for private life at EU level requires that derogations from and limitations on the protection of personal data should apply only in so far as is strictly necessary.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text of PNR Directive was ambiguous on databases and criteria; Court shifted to principle of strict necessity to require narrow interpretation limiting automated processing to what is strictly necessary.

holdings.direction_justification: Court imposes strict interpretive limits on PNR Directive requiring narrow construction of data categories, assessment criteria, and processing purposes to protect fundamental rights.

balancing.necessity_summary: The Court applies strict necessity standard, requiring that derogations from data protection apply only in so far as strictly necessary, limiting automated processing and data retention.
balancing.balance_summary: Court requires balancing between security objectives and data subject privacy, with strict limits on data categories, automated processing, and non-discriminatory criteria favoring data subjects.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection prevails by requiring strict necessity, Charter-conforming interpretation, and limiting surveillance to what is strictly necessary despite security objectives.

holdings.core_holding: National legislation cannot authorize PNR data processing for purposes other than those expressly listed in Article 1(2) of the PNR Directive, such as intelligence service monitoring.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 1(2) of the PNR Directive states expressly that the PNR data collected in accordance with that directive may be processed only for the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offences and serious crime.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is thus clear from the wording of those provisions that the list included therein of the objectives pursued by the processing of PNR data under the PNR Directive is exhaustive.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That interpretation is supported by recital 11 of the PNR Directive, according to which the processing of PNR data should be proportionate to the specific security goals pursued by that directive.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 1(2) of the PNR Directive states expressly that the PNR data collected may be processed only for the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offences and serious crime.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The exhaustive nature of the purposes set out in Article 1(2) means also that PNR data may not be retained in a single database that may be consulted both for those as well as other purposes.

holdings.direction_justification: Precludes expansion of PNR data use to intelligence services or purposes beyond the directive's explicit objectives, limiting data processing scope.

holdings.core_holding: The PIU cannot also be designated as the competent authority to approve disclosure of PNR data after six months, as it lacks the required independence.

interpretation.semantic_quote: It follows from that wording that the other competent national authority thus referred to is an alternative to the judicial authority and, accordingly, must have a level of independence and impartiality similar to the latter.
interpretation.systematic_quote: That analysis is supported by the objective of the PNR Directive, mentioned in recital 25 thereof, to ensure the highest level of data protection concerning access to the full PNR data.
interpretation.teleological_quote: That same recital specifies that that access should be granted only under very strict conditions after the period of six months following the transfer of PNR data to the PIU.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 12(3)(b) of the PNR Directive requires that disclosure be approved by a judicial authority or another national authority competent under national law to verify whether the conditions for disclosure are met.
reasoning.case_law_quote: According to the settled case-law, it is essential that access to retained data by the competent authorities be subject to a prior review carried out either by a court or by an independent administrative body.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The requirement of independence that the body responsible for carrying out the prior review must satisfy also means that that body must be a third party in relation to the authority which requests access to the data.

holdings.direction_justification: Strengthens procedural safeguards by requiring independent approval for data disclosure, preventing PIU from being both data processor and disclosure approver.

holdings.core_holding: A general five-year PNR data retention period is unlawful; retention beyond six months requires objective material establishing a terrorism or serious crime risk for the specific passenger.

interpretation.semantic_quote: The period during which PNR data are to be retained should be as long as is necessary for and proportionate to the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offences and serious crime.
interpretation.systematic_quote: The interpretation of Article 12(1) of the PNR Directive must take into account the provisions in paragraphs 2 and 3 of that article, which lay down a set of rules for the retention of and access to PNR data.
interpretation.teleological_quote: According to recital 25, those provisions seek to avoid disproportionate use through masking out of those data and to ensure the highest level of data protection.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Under Article 12(1) and (4) of that directive, the PIU retains the PNR data provided by air carriers in a database for a period of five years after their transfer.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The Court has already held in Opinion 1/15 that the retention of PNR data for a period of time which has already been described as being particularly long must satisfy objective criteria that establish a connection between the data and the objective pursued.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The retention of PNR data pursuant to Article 12(1) cannot be justified in the absence of an objective connection between that retention and the objectives pursued by that directive.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text allowed five-year retention; Court shifted to strict necessity principle requiring differentiated retention based on risk assessment, limiting general retention to six months.

holdings.direction_justification: Significantly limits data retention by requiring individualized risk assessment; general retention beyond six months for passengers without risk indicators is prohibited.

balancing.necessity_summary: Court applies strict necessity standard: continued storage beyond six months requires objective material establishing a terrorism/crime risk connection with specific passengers.
balancing.balance_summary: Data subject interest in limited retention prevails over general security interest in maintaining comprehensive passenger databases for five years.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection limits prevail; five-year general retention is disproportionate to security objectives absent individualized risk indicators.

holdings.core_holding: The API Directive does not apply to intra-EU flights; it applies only to flights crossing external borders between Member States and third countries.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 3(1) of the API Directive provides that Member States are to take the necessary steps to establish an obligation for carriers to transmit information concerning the passengers they will carry to an authorised border crossing point through which these persons will enter the territory of a Member State.
interpretation.systematic_quote: It is clear from those provisions, read in the light of Article 2(a), (b) and (d) of the API Directive, that that directive imposes the obligation for air carriers only in the case of flights transporting passengers to an authorised crossing point for crossing the Member States' external borders with third countries.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 3(1) of the API Directive provides that Member States are to establish an obligation for carriers to transmit information concerning passengers they will carry to an authorised border crossing point through which these persons will enter the territory of a Member State.

holdings.direction_justification: Clarifies territorial scope of API Directive without expanding or restricting data subject rights within that directive's framework.

holdings.core_holding: Extension of PNR system to all intra-EU flights requires genuine terrorist threat; otherwise must be limited to selected flights with specific indications, and cannot serve border control or immigration purposes.

interpretation.semantic_quote: Article 45 of the Charter guarantees the right of every citizen of the European Union to move and reside freely within the territory of the Member States.
interpretation.systematic_quote: Article 67(2) TFEU provides that the European Union is to ensure the absence of internal border controls for persons and to frame a common policy on external border control.
interpretation.teleological_quote: A national measure that is liable to obstruct the exercise of freedom of movement for persons may be justified only where such a measure is consistent with the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Charter.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Article 2(1) of the PNR Directive, read in conjunction with recital 10 thereof, provides only that Member States may extend the application of the system established by that directive to intra-EU flights.
reasoning.case_law_quote: In accordance with the Court's established case-law, national legislation which places certain nationals at a disadvantage simply because they have exercised their freedom to move is a restriction of the freedoms conferred by Article 45(1) of the Charter.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: An objective of general interest may not be pursued without having regard to the fact that it must be reconciled with the fundamental rights affected by the measure, by properly balancing the objective against the rights at issue.
reasoning.level_shifting_explanation: Text permitted extension to intra-EU flights without restriction; Court shifted to free movement and proportionality principles requiring genuine threat justification or targeted selection.

holdings.direction_justification: Significantly restricts Member State power to extend PNR system to intra-EU transport; requires genuine terrorist threat or targeted selection with regular review.

balancing.necessity_summary: Court applies strict necessity: blanket extension to all intra-EU flights requires genuine and present or foreseeable terrorist threat; otherwise must target specific routes.
balancing.balance_summary: Data subject privacy and free movement interests prevail over general security rationale absent genuine terrorist threat justifying blanket intra-EU surveillance.
balancing.rights_balance_summary: Data protection and free movement prevail; extension of PNR surveillance to all intra-EU transport without genuine threat is disproportionate restriction on fundamental freedoms.

holdings.core_holding: National courts cannot limit temporal effects of declaring national PNR legislation illegal; evidence admissibility is for national law subject to equivalence and effectiveness principles.

interpretation.systematic_quote: The principle of the primacy of EU law establishes the pre-eminence of EU law over the law of the Member States, requiring all Member State bodies to give full effect to the various provisions of EU law.
interpretation.teleological_quote: Maintaining the effects of national legislation would mean that that legislation would continue to impose on air carriers and other carriers obligations which are contrary to EU law and which seriously interfere with the fundamental rights.

reasoning.rule_based_quote: Only the Court may, in exceptional cases, on the basis of overriding considerations of legal certainty, allow the temporary suspension of the ousting effect of a rule of EU law.
reasoning.case_law_quote: The primacy and uniform application of EU law would be undermined if national courts had the power to give provisions of national law primacy in relation to EU law contravened by those provisions, even temporarily.
reasoning.principle_based_quote: The principle of the primacy of EU law establishes the pre-eminence of EU law over the law of the Member States.

holdings.direction_justification: Prevents national courts from temporarily maintaining illegal surveillance legislation, ensuring immediate effect of Charter-based invalidity findings.
